Ha sido para él muy satisfactorio sacar a sus hijos adelante con lo poco que en esos momentos tenían, su esposa  es y ha sido un pilar fundamental en su vida y en su hogar ya que por la necesidad ha tenido que salir a trabajar además ella es quien en un inicio empezó con la crianza y venta de animales menores.
Con el esfuerzo de sus padres pudo terminar la primaria, por la difícil situación económica  de su familia tuvo que trabajar desde muy pequeño y así poder ser un gran apoyo para él y su familia. Aprendió de esta actividad ya que es muy común en la zona, por ser un sector rural, trabaja de 6 a 8 horas diarias en el cuidado de los animales.
Se le hace un poco difícil el transportar su ganado para las diferentes ferias ya que no cuenta con un transporte propio para ello, pero pese a esto no se ha hecho mayor problema, al contrario le ha motivado para salir adelante por el bien de él y el de su familia.  Por el momento solicita un crédito de $700 dólares para poder adquirir una vaca lechera, la misma que servirá para obtener más rentabilidad utilidad con la venta de la leche.
Jorge y su esposa  quieren extender un sincero agradecimiento y felicitación a Fundación Alternativa en Ecuador y a Kiva por hacer posible el crecimiento en su vida laboral y personal.
texts.en:
José was born in the city in the parish of Toacazo in Latacunga province, part of the Republico of Ecuador. This area is defined by its inhabitants who make a living raising and selling small animals and cattle for milk and meat. José is 48 years old and currently married. At the moment, he has one dependent child. They have been living in their own house for 49 years.

It has been very fulfilling for him to help his children get ahead with the little that they have at this time. His wife is and has been a strong pillar in his life and home because of his need to leave to work. In addition it was she who started raising and selling small animals.

Due to his parent’s labor, he was able to finish primary school. However, because of his family’s difficult economic situation he had to start working when he was very young. Thus he was able to be a great source of support for himself and his family.

He learned this business because it is very common in the area, since it is a rural sector. He works from 6 to 8 hours a day caring for his animals. It has been a little difficult to transport his cattle to the different markets because he does not have his own transportation. Nevertheless, despite this it has not been a major problem. On the contrary it has motivated him to get ahead for his own and his family’s wellbeing 

At the moment, he is requesting a loan of $700 so that he can buy a milk cow. This will enable him to earn more profits by selling milk. 

Jorge and his wife want to extent their sincere appreciation and congratulations to Fundación Alternative in Ecuador and to Kiva for making their growth, both professional and personal, possible.

loans.use: to purchase a milk cow and increase his profits.

loans.name: Nahartenga Group

texts.fr:
Mr IDRISSA ZACKARIE représente le groupe NAHARTENGA. Marié, il est père de 06enfants. Le plus âgé a 22ans et le moins âgé a 04ans. 04 vont à l’école et il a 09personnes en charge.
Il est cultivateur et fait l’élevage  depuis 35ans. Il s’approvisionne au marché de son village. Ses clients viennent de Ouagadougou.
Mr veut s’acheter 02 moutons.
Il veut réinvestir ses bénéfices dans son activité. Mr ambitionne construire une maison d’habitation et payer 02 motos pour sa famille.
texts.en:
Idrissa Zackarie represents the Nahartenga Group.  He is married and has six children, the eldest is 22 years old and the youngest is four years old.  Four of his children attend school and he is financially responsible for nine people.

Idrissa Zackarie has been a livestock farmer for 35 years.  He buys his supplies at the local village market, and sells to customers who come from Ouagadougou.  Idrissa Zackarie will use his loan to buy two sheep, and his earnings will be reinvested in his business.  

In the future, he would like to build a house and buy two motorcycles for his family.

loans.use: to buy 2 sheep.

loans.name: Yorleny María

texts.es:
Yorleny María Morera es una mujer de 35 años, ella vive en Paraíso de Pocosol, es soltera y no tiene hijos, vive con sus padres y se dedica a la crianza de terneros, actividad que realiza desde hace más de 2 años la cual le gusta mucho.

Yorleny María realiza su actividad en una finca cerca de su casa, a la cual viaja caminando todos los días para cuidar de sus terneros. Ella está solicitando este crédito para comprar más terneros y poder incrementar el hato de ganado que posee.

Con la compra de estos terneros ella espera recibir ingresos de 420.000 colones cada 5 meses, para poder solventar las necesidades diarias de ella y sus padres.

Ella vende su ganado en la Subasta Ganadera de Muelle, allí encuentra sus clientes.

El negocio que tiene Yorleny María es muy importante para ella porque puede brindarle bienestar a su familia con el dinero que recibe, además la hace sentirse orgullosa porque tiene un trabajo digno, justo y hace lo que más le gusta que es trabajar con animales.

Este préstamo le ayudará a mejorar sus finanzas y a incrementar el hato de ganado que tiene y así poder brindarle una mejor calidad de vida a sus padres.
texts.en:
Yorleny Maria is a 35 year old woman who lives in Paraiso de Pocosol. She is single and has no children. Yorleny lives with her parents and dedicates herself to raising calves, an activity she has pursued for more than 2 years and likes very much. Yorleny does this on a ranch near her house and she goes there every day to care for her calves.
Yorleny is requesting this loan to purchase more calves and, thus, to increase her herd of cattle. With the purchase of these calves, she hopes to receive an income of 420,000 colons each 5 months, enough to cover the daily expenses of herself and her parents. Yorleny sells her cattle in the Subasta Ganadera de Muelle where she finds her customers. Her business is very important for her because with it, she can provide for the wellbeing of her family with the money she earns. In addition, it makes her proud because she has worthwhile and just work. What she likes most is working with animals. This loan will help her to improve her finances and to augment her herd of cattle and, thus, offer a better quality of life for her parents.

loans.use: buy calves to raise.

loans.name: Ndiague's Group

texts.fr:
Inauguré depuis le 13 décembre 2008, ce groupe évolue grâce à l'élan de solidarité des membres qui font comme activité principale le petit commerce.
Ndiague, debout à droite de la Photo et levant la main est âgée de 62 ans. Elle est veuve et mère de 09 enfants dont 06 filles. Elle fait comme activité principale le petit commerce. Elle vend des légumes et du poisson au marché qui se trouve dans sa localité. Elle développe cette activité depuis fort longtemps et a une très bonne expérience dans ce domaine. Elle fait comme activité parallèle l'élevage de poussins. Elle va acheter pour 66 000 F de poissons et de légumes. Avec le reste, elle va acheter 40 Kg de (niébé) haricot local à 300 F / kg, 200 Kg de mil à 300 F / Kg. Elle va aussi acheter des poussins pour un montant de 50 000 f et 12 000 F seront consacrés aux vaccins et à l'entretien.
Les bénéfices vont servir à améliorer son quotidien (nourriture) et à renforcer son épargne.
texts.en:
This group was created on 13 December 2008, and has been driven by the commitment to solidarity shown by its members, who mainly work in small-scale retail.

Ndiague, who is pictured standing to the right with her hand raised, is 62 years of age. She is a widow and has nine children, six of whom are girls. Her main business is small-scale retail, and she sells vegetables and fish in the market in her town. She has been working in this business for a long time now, and has a lot of experience in this field. In addition, she also works rearing chickens.

Ndiague will use 66,000 francs of her loan to buy fish and vegetables. With the rest, she plans to buy 40 kilos of ‘niébé’ (a local bean) at 300 francs per kilo, as well as 200 kilos of millet at 300 francs per kilo. She also plans to buy chicks for 50,000 francs, as well as spending 12,000 francs on vaccinations and expenses for looking after her chicks.

Ndiague will use the profits she makes to improve her daily life (food), as well as to increase her savings.

loans.use: To buy vegetables and fish

loans.name: Daba's Group

texts.fr:
Ce groupe fait partie d'un Banc villageois a été créé le 13 décembre 2008. Il est constitué de femmes habitant le même village et qui font comme principales activités le commerce et l'embouche. Les femmes entretiennent de très bonnes relations entre elles.
Daba, debout à droite de la photo et levant la main est âgée de 33 ans. Elle est mariée et est mère de 04 enfants dont 02 garçons. Elle fait comme activité principale l'embouche ovine. Elle pratique cette activité depuis très longtemps avant même d'intégrer le BV. Avec le crédit, elle va acheter 10 moutons à 30 000 F l'un. Elle va acheter de la nourriture pour bétail à 100 000 F et les 10 000 F qui restent vont servir au transport. Elle compte élever les moutons et au bout de 05 mois les revendre à 50 000 f l'un.
Avec les bénéfices, elle va renforcer son épargne et entretenir ses petits enfants.
texts.en:
This group belongs to a Banc Villageois created on 13 December 2008. It consists of women who live in the same village and whose main activities are commerce and livestock fattening. They all get along very well. 

Daba, age 33, is the group member standing on the right and raising her hand. She is married with four children, two boys and two girls. 

Daba’s main business activity is sheep fattening, something she has been doing for a very long time, even before joining the BV. She will use her loan to buy ten sheep at 30,000 F each, and 100,000 F worth of feed. The remaining 10,000 F will be used to cover transportation costs. She plans to fatten the sheep and sell them after five months for 50,000 F each.  

She will use her profits to bolster her savings and to provide for her young children.

loans.use: to buy sheep for fattening.

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en: Tessie helps her husband to work in their farm for it is their main source of income. She has been doing this for five years, and she was able to provide for the needs of her four children. She borrowed a loan from GDMPC Micro Credit to buy seedlings and fertilizer to improve her farm. She is hopeful to add a new plot of vegetables to earn more income for the family's needs.

loans.use: to buy seedlings and fertilizer.

loans.name: Gehobanis Antonio

texts.es:
Gehobanis de 32 años,  es una persona acompañada, ha procreado tres hijos y realizo sus estudios hasta  bachillerato en la ciudad.

 Se levanta a las 5:00 a.m. Junto a su esposa e hijos, quienes asisten a la escuela y dependen de las actividades que realiza.  Èl se dedica a la agricultura, oficio que aprendió de sus padres.  Para llegar a la parcelas camina 1.5 Km y trabaja durante la mañana y su esposa se dedica a los oficios domésticos y a cuidar las vacas que posee; en la  la noche se dedica a cuidar una finca

El préstamo que esta solicitando a Fundación Campo, es para comprar una yunta de bueyes, que necesita para poder arar la tierra donde cultiva y obtener un ingreso adicional por arar otras parcelas, lo que le ayudara a mantener a su familia.

Espera  en un futuro, construir una vivienda digna, para su familia ya que actualmente vive en una de adobe.

loans.use: para comprar una yunta de bueyes, que necesita para poder arar la tierra donde cultiva.

loans.name: Rosas De Florida Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “ROSAS DE FLORIDA” iniciará el tercer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Villa Adela, está compuesta por ocho  integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Valeria es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: tienda de barrio, reciclaje de plástico, venta de comida, fundido de metales, venta de enaguas, venta de golosinas, servicio de lavandería.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Valeria es integrante, ella indica que hace dos años que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por la invitación de una promotora de la institución que fue a visitarle a su casa. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de reciclaje de plásticos; da a conocer que este negocio lo aprendió hace varios años, al observar que este material desechable podría ser vendido.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de botellas de plástico) que adquirirá de las recicladoras por menor que le entregan en su tienda de la Ciudad de El Alto y posteriormente lo comercializará en las empresas de reciclaje. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para mantener a su familia, ya que ella es casada y tiene dos hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta el área de crédito, salud y capacitación que le ofrece la institución.

En la fotografía no se encuentra una de las socias porque se encontraba en consulta médica.
texts.en:
The "Rosas De Florida" communal bank will start its third cycle in Pro Mujer, as part of the Villa Adela regional office. It has eight members and is headed by a board of directors, of which Valeria is the president. The members of the organization engage in a variety of businesses, which include a neighborhood store, plastic recycling, selling foods, metal casting, selling skirts, selling sweets, and laundry service.

The loan they will take out will benefit small micro-enterprises, including Valeria. She says that she has been a member of Pro Mujer for two years, after joining through the invitation of the institution's representative who visited her home. Currently she has a plastic recycling business and reveals that she learned this business several years ago upon discovering that this disposable material could be sold.

The loan they will take out is for increasing capital by purchasing plastic bottles, which she will acquire retail from recyclers that deliver to her store in Ciudad de El Alto and subsequently ....  recycling businesses. This type of work allows her to generate income to support her family, as she's married and has two children.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she answers that she likes what the institution offers in terms of loans, health, and training.

One of the group members is not pictured because she was at a medical appointment.

loans.use: To purchase plastic bottles.

loans.name: Anibal

texts.en:
Anibal is an entrepreneur who has developed a small business that produces and sells fuel-efficient Ecocina cookstoves in Copan Ruinas, Honduras. These stoves eliminate smoke from the home, reduce wood consumption by 50%, and save families time collecting firewood. His E'Copan stove factory employs six people and has sold more than 5,000 stoves in three years. Prior to becoming a 'stover,' Anibal worked in agroforestry and served as vice mayor of the town of Copan Ruinas. 

Anibal would like to expand his business throughout Honduras in order to reach more families who are still cooking over dangerous open fires. In order to do this, Anibal is requesting a Kiva loan to create a distribution center in Ocotepeque, Honduras. Anibal's nephew Manuel will be able to order 50 Ecocina stoves on credit from E’Copan, and the Kiva loan will be repaid as soon as the stoves are sold. Manuel and his wife will both be employed, and their business will save lives by increasing the number of families using safe, efficient cookstoves. Eventually Anibal would like to establish eight distribution centers throughout Honduras.

loans.use: to create a distribution center for fuel-efficient cookstoves.

loans.name: Aminata

texts.en:
Greetings from Sierra Leone! This is 45-year-old Aminata from Waterloo2 eastern rural area in Freetown. She is married and blessed with 4 children. She started her business to take care of her family. 

Aminata runs a food stand business at home; she sells rice, onions and cooking seasonings. She has been running this business since 2010. She works at her business throughout the week, from morning until night. Aminata says that the main challenges to her business are price, transportation and insufficient capital to expand her business.

Aminata has requested a loan in order to buy more cooking items like rice, onions and cooking seasonings. The extra income from this loan will allow her to educate her children and increase her business. In the future, she plans to expand her business. She thanks you for your support!

loans.use: to buy more cooking items like rice, onions and cooking seasonings.

loans.name: Frank

texts.en:
Frank is 34 years old and lives in the town of Rukoki in the region of Fort Portal in Uganda. He is married and has two children. For the past two years, Frank has been working hard to manage his video library, which sells various movies and music.

To help expand his business, Frank has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy printers, covers and accessories for the business, and will help Frank to generate greater profits and to expand the business. Frank hopes that, in the future, he will be able to to add more money to the business. 

Frank is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Frank who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy printers, covers and accessories for the business.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
Meet Hawa. She is 34 years old and from Jui, an eastern area in Freetown. She is single with no child for now. In 2003, Hawa established her retails business. She began her business because she wants to empower herself. She works at the business from 8:00am until 7:00pm, 7 days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is insufficient capital to expand her business.

Hawa requires a loan in order to purchase more toothpaste, cream, and shirt to expand her business. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to change her standard of living and grow her business. In the future, Hawa plans to open a food stand table. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more toothpaste, cream, and shirt to expand her business

loans.name: Samuel

texts.fr: Samuel est un homme de 36 marié père de 05 enfants dont l'age varie entre 10 et 16 ans. Il est commerçant et à ouvert un petit kiosque qu'il gère lui même depuis 3 ans. c'est grâce à son petit commerce qu'il subvient aux besoins de sa famille. son petit commerce marche bien, mais se pose un problème de rupture permanente de son stock ( lait, sucreries, cigarettes, crédit de communication...)ceci à cause de la petitesse de son capital qui l'oblige à faire écouler une bonne partie de son stock avant de se réapprovisionner. d'où l'importance de ce crédit qui permettra d'augmenter non seulement ses ventes, mais aussi sa marge bénéficiaire. benéfice qui sera en partie réinvesti dans son activité et le reste l'aidera à subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.
texts.en: Samuel is a 36-year old man who is married and father to five children, ranging from 10 to 16 years old. He is a trader and has set up a small stand which he has been managing himself for the past three years. Thanks to this small business he is able to provide for his family's needs. Although his business is working well, he has a permanent shortage of stock owing to the small amount of capital he has, and this obliges him to sell off a large part of his stock before he is able to replenish it. This loan is thus important to him because it will enable him not only to increase his sales, but also his profit margin. His profits will be partly reinvested in his business and the rest will be used to provide for his family's needs.

loans.use: to increase his stock.

loans.name: Koem

texts.en:
Koem is 44 years old and a married woman. She has three children, one of whom is married and lives separately. Like other local villager, Koem is in the business of farming rice in Bakan district, Pursat province. Farming rice is a very popular business and is a major source of income for the people in the region. Koem has been doing this for almost 20 years and earns a normal income of $4 per day.

In order to improve the sanitation and increase their personal hygiene, Koem would like to build a household latrine as she doesn’t have one yet. Due to inadequate capital, she is asking for a loan of 1,000 US dollars to buy construction supplies needed for constructing a latrine and pay for labor costs. She is able to request this loan thanks to the water loan program offered by HKL and Kiva with a special interest rate, which has encouraged her to focus on healthy living conditions, safeguarding the health of her family and protecting the environment.

loans.use: to buy construction supplies needed for building a latrine and pay for labor costs.

loans.name: Rossa's Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Camp de Garde  est créé le 02 Novembre  2006  au jour de l’inauguration du banc villageois. Il est composé de  femmes qui habitent le même quartier. Elles ont une expérience solide dans le programme des bancs villageois pour avoir fait plusieurs cycles pour la majorité de ses membres.. Elles ont comme activité principale le petit commerce.

Madame  Rossa, (debout à l’extrême  droite avec une main levée), est l’emprunteuse vedette  du groupe.  Agée de 53 ans, elle est veuve et actuellement elle prend en charge ses 04 enfants dont 02 garçons et filles. C’est une femme d’une volonté et détermination sans faille. Elle s’active dans la vente de divers produits : huile de palm, jus de citron, fruits de mère. Elle jouit d’une grande expérience dans cette Activité pour l’avoir pratiqué pendant plusieurs années.

Avec ce prêt elle compte acheter 05 bidons d’huile de palm qu’elle revendra au prix de 1 000 F CFA le litre, du jus de citron vendu à 700 F CFA le litre et des fruits de mère suivant la disponibilité.

Les bénéfices de son activité lui permettront d’épargner d’une part et  d’assurer la prise en charge de sa famille surtout tous les plans.
texts.en:
The Camp de Garde Group was created on 2nd November 2006, the day the banc villageois opened. This group is made up of women who live in the same district. They have solid experience in the organisation of bancs villageois, with the majority of members having taken out several loans with them already. Their main sources of revenue come from the retail sector.

Rossa (the woman with her hand raised in the far right of the photo) is the group's star borrower. Aged 53, she is a widow and she currently cares for four children, two boys and two girls. She is a highly driven woman with unshakable determination. She works as a vendor of many different products: palm oil, lemon juice and seafood. She has gained much experience in this sector after having worked in it for several years.

With this loan, she plans to purchase five containers of palm oil, which she will resell at 1000 F CFA per litre, lemon juice at 700 F CFA per litre and seafood, depending on availability.

The profits from this business will allow her to put some money aside and assure her family's well-being for the future.

loans.use: to purchase five containers of palm oil, which she will resell at 1000 F CFA per litre, lemon juice at 700 F CFA per litre and seafood, depending on availability.

loans.name: Ramata's Group

texts.fr:
Ce  groupe  créé le 04 Juillet  2008 lors de l’inauguration leur banc villageois. Il compte en son sein des femmes qui habitent toutes dans le même village. Elles partagent des valeurs de solidarité et entre aide qui caractérisent leurs actions et relations entre membre. Le banc villageois est à son onzième cycle ce qui fait que les femmes jouissent d’une bonne expérience dans le petit commerce qui constitue leur activité  principale.

Madame Ramata  (assise l’extrême droite avec la main droite levée), est l’emprunteuse vedette du groupe. Elle est mariée et mère de 03 enfants dont 02 filles. Elle s’est spécialisée dans la vente de légumes plus précisément la vente d’aubergine et de piment, activité qui lui respectivement rapporte après chaque tourné un bénéfice nette de 25 000  et 7 000 F CFA.

Avec ce prêt, elle compte achèter auprès des producteurs des aubergines pour une valeur de 100 000 F CFA et du piment pour un montant de 30 000 F CFA.

 Les bénéfices lui servent d’une part à participer de manière significative aux dépenses quotidiennes de nourriture et scolaire pendant la période des études et d’autres part à accroître son épargner.
texts.en:
This group was created on 4th July 2008 at the same time as their banc villageois was inaugurated. It is comprised of women who all live in the same village. They share the values of solidarity and collaboration, which is reflected in their actions and their inter-member relationships. The banc villageois is working with its eleventh loan, meaning that these women have solid experience within the retail sector, which is their main source of income.

Ramata (the woman sat on the far right with her hand raised in the photo) is the group's star borrower. She specialises in selling vegetables; aubergines and chilis, to be precise. This business earns her a net profit of 25,000 F CFA.

With this loan, she plans to purchase aubergines for 100,00 F CFA and chilis for 30,000 F CFA from producers.

The profits will be used in part to significantly contribute towards daily food and study needs during the school period, the rest will go towards increasing her savings.

loans.use: to purchase aubergines for 100,00 F CFA and chilis for 30,000 F CFA from producers

loans.name: Lay

texts.en:
Lay is 25 years old (she is not available in the picture). She is married and resides with two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. She has been selling souvenirs for more than a year, earning approximately $3 per day. Her husband (who is in the picture) is a construction worker. He makes an income of $5 each day. 

Due to lack of funds, Lay is requesting a loan of $500 to purchase timber to build her house. This money will help her provide better living conditions for her family. In the future, she would like to expand her business and send her children to a good school.

loans.use: to purchase timber to build her house

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a small scale egg seller at Yabiw (near Takoradi). She has had some form of formal education as she is a junior high school graduate. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a driver. 

Beatrice has worked in the egg business for close to nine years. Her income is used to help her husband pay the utility bills and their children’s school fees. She plans on using her loan to purchase an increased quantity of eggs, thus allowing her to meet rising customers’ demands. She hopes to use the profits from her enterprise to fulfill her dream of owning an egg stand, hence helping her sell from a fixed location in the future.

loans.use: to purchase an increased quantity of eggs, thus allowing her to meet rising customers’ demands.

loans.name: Joan

texts.en: Joan is a resident of Birere, in Isingiro District, with four biological children all in school. She started a small retail shop some 20 years back but could not yield anything because of limited capital. That is when she got to know about Ugafode Microfinance and acquired a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan shillings (UGX), which helped increase her retail business's growth, and because of her hard work she continued expanding and eventually made enough money and started building a residential house for her children. Now she is requesting a loan of 5,000,000 UGX to buy construction materials to finish her house.

loans.use: to buy building materials

loans.name: Singam Diom Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de crédit Singam Diom est le nom d’une association de femmes habitant cote à cote dans le même village. Après avoir bien réfléchi à l’idée d’appuyer leur mari dans les charges de la maison, ces femmes se sont regroupées  afin de pouvoir bénéficier de crédit pour pouvoir s’activer dans le petit commerce. Elles sont au nombre de six et sont ici représentées par trois d’entre elles dont la présidente qui est reconnue comme tenant des épis de mil. 
Elle s’appelle Oumy, elle a 35 ans, mariée et mère d’une fille de 9 ans. Madame Oumy, est récemment entré dans le commerce avec la vente de poisson séché et d’autres variétés de fruits de mer. Elle a démarré avec un capital de 100.000FCFA constitué à partir de ses économies. Elle n’a pas de charges et ses bénéfices sont refinancés dans l’activité.
Elle désire agrandir son commerce un jour.
texts.en:
The loan group Singam Diom is an association of women who live next to one another in the same village. After thinking hard about supporting their husbands with the household expenses, the women joined forces so that they could take advantage of a loan and get involved in a small business.

They are a group of six, and are represented here by three of the women. The president is the one holding ears of millet.

Her name is Oumy. She is 35 years old, married, and the mother of a nine-year-old daughter. Madame Oumy recently went into business by selling dried fish and other types of seafood. She started with 100,000 FCFA from her savings. She does not have expenses, and her profits are put back into her business. One day, she would like to grow her business.

loans.use: buy dried fish and other seafood for resale.

loans.name: Fabiola

texts.es:
Fabiola es clienta de Kubo Financiero y esta es su historia:

Fabiola es maestra de educación secundaria y es algo que la satisface plenamente. Vive con sus padres y el sueño de su madre, y el suyo también, es tener una casa bonita y funcional; ya que ahora el espacio es reducido.

Aparte de ser maestra, Fabiola comparte un taller de maquila de ropa con su mamá que atiende cuando tiene tiempo. Este préstamo le proporcionaría las herramientas que necesita ahora para cumplir el sueño de su madre y el suyo; ampliar su casa. 

Fabiola no tiene deudas y no ha tramitado tarjetas, porque cree que sólo en casos de urgencia se deben usar; el único crédito que tiene está en ceros.
texts.en:
Fabiola is a client of Kubo Financiero and this is her story:

Fabiola is a secondary school teacher and this is something that fully satisfies her.  She lives with her parents.  Her mother's dream, as well as her own, is to have a beautiful and functional house because right now the space is limited.

Apart from being a teacher, Fabiola shares a clothing workshop with her mother which she tends to when she has time.  This loan will provide the tools that she needs now in order to complete her mother's and her own dream of expanding their home.

Fabiola has no debt and has not applied for credit cards because she believes that they should only be used in cases of emergency.  The only loan that she has taken out has been depleted.

loans.use: to make improvements to her home.

loans.name: Scovia

texts.en:
Scovia is 38 years old and lives in the town of Mityana in the region of Mubende in Uganda. She is married and has five children with four of them currently in school. For the past four years, Scovia has been working hard to manage her poultry farm, which sales eggs and off-layers. 

To help expand her business, Scovia has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more eggs and off-layers, and will help Scovia generate greater profits and pay family expenses and make profits. Scovia hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her poultry project into a bigger farm. 

Scovia is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs similar to Scovia who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro-loans.

loans.use: Buy more eggs and off-layers for her poultry business.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
As a married parent of six children, Rosemarie works hard to support her family.

She has a business buying and selling fruits and vegetables in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from selling coconut lumber. Rosemarie is borrowing PHP 19,500 through NWTF to buy additional fruits and vegetables to sell in her fruit and vegetable business.

Rosemarie has been sustaining her business activities through her past 12 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy additional fruits and vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Deysi De Jesus

texts.es: Deysi de 49 años de edad vive en casa propia con su esposo, ella se dedica a la elaboración y venta de pupusas desde hace 12 años su negocio lo tiene ubicado en su lugar de residencia, posee mucha clientela por los buenos precios, con lo que obtiene de su negocio logar cubrir algunos gastos de su hogar, Deysi esta solicitando un crédito para la compra de los ingredientes necesarios como: chicharrón, quesillo, frijoles, maíz, tomates, etc. para poder seguir elaborando las pupusas y asi obtener mejores ganancias y tener una mejor vida junto a su esposo.
texts.en:
Deysi, 49, lives in her own house with her husband. She has been making and selling “pupusas” (traditional Salvadoran dish – thick, hand-made corn tortillas) for 12 years. Her business is located in her home. She has many clients due to her good prices. She is able to pay some household expenses with her earnings from her work. 

Deysi is requesting a loan to purchase ingredients such as: pork rinds, fresh cheese, beans, corn, tomatoes etc... to be able to continue making pupusas and to generate better profits and to have a better life with her husband.

loans.use: to purchase pork rinds, fresh cheese, beans, corn, tomatoes etc...

loans.name: Pedro

texts.en:
This is Pedro, 47, resident of Tondo, Manila, Philippines. Single, he manages his household while operating the business. At this time, he is working hard to provide income for his everyday expenses continually and help his parents financially.

Pedro operates a salon business. He offers hair styling, hair grooming and services. He also offers hair straightening. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. His salon is located adjacent to his house. He also has a variety store for additional income. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of 1,000 PHP in sales every day.

To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a PHP 20,000 loan. He will be utilizing the loan to buy supplies for his salon such as shampoo, hair treatment creams and oils, and other things needed for his business.

Pedro dreams to be a big businessman someday and hopes to support his family and give them a good future. He meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his life and business every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for beauty products and hair products needed in his salon.

loans.name: Rosa Ma

texts.es:
Rosa es clienta de Kubo Financiero y esta es su historia:

Rosa es casada, su esposo se llama Fidel, y tiene cuatro hijos. Ella es una persona que lucha para salir adelante, quiere tener una estabilidad económica y pretende con ello en unos años más tener una vida tranquila.

Ella tiene un negocio de venta de artículos religiosos desde hace 15 años donde elabora rosarios, lazos, pulseras y cristos. Todos sus productos los realiza manualmente con ayuda de su esposo e hijo, sus clientes son negocios de casas de novias en diferentes estados del país como Michoacán, Morelos, Veracruz e Hidalgo. Aparte, en sus ratos libres le dedica tiempo a la iglesia.

Con este préstamo pretende invertir en su negocio comprando cristal cortado, cadena, alambre, cristos, broches, madonas y cristal de segunda. Gracias al trabajo en su negocio Rosa ha logrado terminar de construir su casa y hacer prosperar su negocio; su principal reto es seguir hacer creciendo su negocio.
texts.en:
Rosa is a member of the group “Kubo Financiero”, and this is her story: She is married, her husband’s name is Fidel, and they have 4 children. She is a person who works hard to get ahead, and she wishes to obtain economic stability, so that her life in the coming years may be more pleasant.

During the last 15 years she has been running a business of religious artifacts, making rosaries, bows, bracelets and crosses. These are all hand-made items that she makes with the help of her husband and their son. Her customers mainly include bridal shops in different regions of the country (like Michoacán, Morelos, Veracruz e Hidalgo). She dedicates her free time to activities in the church.

Rosa plans to use this loan to invest in buying supplies for her business, like lead glass, decorative chains, wire, crosses, brooches, virgin statues, and second-hand lead glass.

Thanks to her work Rosa was able to finish with the construction of her house, while also developing her business. Her main challenge is to continue to make her business grow.

loans.use: to buy supplies like lead glass, wire, crosses, brooches, etc.

loans.name: Sarom's Group

texts.en:
Sarorm is 38 years old and married. She lives in a rural village in the Tbaung Khmum district of Kampong Cham province and she has five children. To make a living, she has been farming rice and working for others for a fee. The current business earns her about 23,000 KHR per day to meet the family’s needs. 

Sarorm just started with VisionFund this cycle. Now she is leading her group to ask for a loan. Sarorm, who is the leader, will use her portion to buy fertilizer for her farmland. She hopes to earn more crops from her rice paddy.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her farmland

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Roxanne

texts.en:
This is Roxanne, 38, resident of Payatas, Philippines. She is married to Ronie, a vendor and a mother to their children. She, together with husband, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Roxanne operates a rug-making business. She mainly offers rugs, from those round palm sized ones, to the much larger doormats and other crafts that most rug-makers come up every day. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, rugs are one of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding in a speeding jeepney down the highway. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php26, 000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and other materials for her business. 

Roxanne hopes to expand her business and have more customers and dreams to have a better means of living. She meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her life and business every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread and other materials for her business.

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en:
Anecita is 58 years old and married with seven children.

Anecita works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 17000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stocks to sell like can goods, egg, milk, noodles, etc.

Anecita has borrowed and paid 14 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 7 years and also earns an income from motorcycle transport and farming rice.

Anecita aspires to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks to sell like can goods, egg, milk, noodles, etc

loans.name: Romelle

texts.en:
Romelle is a hardworking entrepreneur who has an internet cafe business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 10000 through NWTF in order to buy supplies for her internet cafe business.

Romelle successfully paid back her previous loan and is now requesting a new loan to further build her business.

NWTF is re-listing Romelle's business profile again in support of her efforts to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her internet cafe.

loans.name: Sitahiti

texts.en: "Sitahiti is 56 years old single mother. She owns and operates a business venture, sewing clothes. She has 10 years of experience in this line of business. Sitahiti needs a loan to buy a sewing machine, materials, threads, and oil.She hopes to use her profits to support her family and to improve her business. She joined SPBD in 2011."

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine, materials, threads, and an oil.

loans.name: Melody

texts.en:
Melody is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a general store business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 20000 through NWTF to buy more items to sell like can goods, bread, egg, milk, sugar, etc for her general store business.

Melody has been in this business for 21 years. Melody earns more income from food vending.

Melody has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell like can goods, bread, egg, milk, sugar, etc

loans.name: Nyamosense B Group

texts.en:
This group is a Nuru International group of five farmers called Nyamosense B. They came together in order to grow socially and economically through agriculture.

Stephen, who is raising up his hand, is 32 years old. He is married with five children. He solely depends on farming to earn a living and is therefore keen on practicing better farming methods. During the 2014 long rains, Stephen will plant a one acre farm with maize on ½ acre and sorghum and millet on ¼ acre each. He is requesting a loan to enable him to purchase farm inputs. With the farm inputs, he is hopeful that the harvest will be good and he will ensure food security for his large family.

loans.use: To purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to grow maize, sorghum and millet

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy second hand clothes to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase raw materials for making mats and additional inventory for her grocery store

loans.name: Charles

texts.en:
Charles is 39 years, married with six children who are all in school.
He deals in coffee farming and trade. He has requested for a loan of 1,200,000 Ugandan shillings to help him purchase more coffee to sell in his business. He hopes this will increase his cash flow. His future plans are to construct a permanent house for his family. His major challenge is poor storage and processes which affect the quality of his coffee thereby lowering its prices.
Despite these challenges, Charles has tried to employ local storage measures and as a result of those efforts, he has a permanent flow of customers.

loans.use: to purchase coffee to sell.

loans.name: Moa Lay Lay Group

texts.en:
In the photo are members of the “Moa Lay Lay” group. They are small-scale business people based in Waterloo, a small town near Freetown,  Sierra Leone’s capital city. This is the first loan these entrepreneurs are accessing from SMT/Kiva lenders. With this loan, they will be able to expand their respective businesses, make more profit and consequently improve their standard of living. 

The featured leader of this group is Mariatu. Mariatu is age 32; she was born in Kambia town, in northern Sierra Leone but she is currently residing in Waterloo, together with her husband and four children. Her husband is a driver and three of her children are attending primary schools. For two years now,  Mariatu has been selling body sprays and body lotions.  With this loan, she will buy a large quantity of body sprays and body lotions to add to her business inventory. 

(Also included in the photo is a disqualified member. Loan Officer discovered later that he was biologically related to another group member).

loans.use: to buy a large quantity of body sprays and body lotions to add to her business inventory

loans.name: Kewandwi B Group

texts.en:
This is a Nuru International group of three farmers, called Kewandwi, and is based within Kuria West district. The members of the group came together in order to grow socially and economically through agriculture.

The person raising his hand up is Juma. He is 22 years old and married with one child. Juma has been a member of the group for two years, and is the group’s chairperson.

Juma has been learning better farming methods within his group, and desires to use hybrid seeds and fertilizers in his farm to grow maize, sorghum and millet during the 2014 long rain seasons. He is, however, constrained financially and is hoping to receive a loan from Kiva, which will enable him to purchase these farm inputs. 

He believes that the use of the hybrid seeds and fertilizer will increase his yields, and he will not only get enough food for his family, but will also sell the surplus and obtain money to invest in a dairy cow.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to grow maize, sorghum, and millet.

loans.name: Jipange Group

texts.en:
Jipange is a Nuru International group of six farmers in Kuria West District in Kenya. The members joined the group to acquire skills and knowledge on improved farming methods. They are able to obtain loans through Nuru International to acquire farm inputs. As a group, the members collectively guarantee the loan.

Josephine, who is raising her hand, is the chairperson of the group and has been a member of the group since the year 2011. She is 35 years old and is married with two children who go to school. The loan from Kiva will enable her to acquire hybrid seeds and fertilizer, which will enable her to obtain high yields. Josephine, just like the other members of her group, will take input loans for one acre. She will grow maize on 1/2 acre, and sorghum and millet on ¼ acre each. She plans to sell the surplus and pay school fees for her children. She also plans to join a saving and loaning scheme so she will save some of the money obtained from selling the surplus. This will give her more financial independence.

loans.use: To purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to grow maize, sorghum and millet

loans.name: Nyangota Kilimo Group

texts.en:
This is a Nuru International group of two farmers called Nyangota Kilimo which is based in the Kuria West district. The members of the group came together in order to grow socially and economically through agriculture.

The person raising his hand is Jacob. He is 35 years old, and is married with two children who go to school. Jacob has been a member of the group for two years and he is the group’s chairperson.

Jacob has been learning better farming methods and he needs to use hybrid seeds and fertilizers on his farm to grow maize, sorghum and millet during the 2014 "long rains" season. However, he is constrained financially. He needs this loan to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer that will increase his harvest yields. He will use his harvest to secure food for his family, and then he plans to sell the surplus and invest in a business in order to obtain enough money to pay for his children’s school fees.

loans.use: To purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to grow maize, sorghum and millet

loans.name: Bughoye Thuyikolere Group

texts.en:
Georget is 32 years old  and married, with two children, one still in school.

She has been in drug shop business for eight years, and she also does farming as additional income. She started her business for self-sustainability and to increase her family income.

She hopes to expand her drug shop and transform it to a big pharmacy in Kasese town.

She is a member of Bughoye Thuyikolere group, where each member guarantees the others to get a loan. However, bad debtors and expiration of drugs are challenges she faces.The photo has captured six out of the eight clients. 

Georget intends to use the loan to buy more drugs to sell.

loans.use: To buy more drugs to sell.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Meet Joseph who is one of our borrowers. He is an established farmer living in Kitale, where he has been involved in farming for 18 years, and which has been his main source of income. He produces and sells milk, and crops like maize. He has a passion for farming because of the returns he gets and it is a source of livelihood for his family. His biggest challenge is seasons of long rains which spoil crops on the farm, and also pests.

Joseph chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan because they have good terms of loan repayment. This loan will help him to pay school fees for his children, and will also uplift their living standards. He really appreciates Juhudi Kilimo for adding value to his farmwork.

loans.use: to purchase poultry.

loans.name: Lillian

texts.en:
Lilian is 41 years old and lives in the town of Paidah in a region of Arua in Uganda. She is married and has three children, who are all currently in school. For the past four years, Lilian has been working hard to manage her fish business, which sells dry fish. 

To help expand her business, Lilian has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more fish, and will help Lilian to generate greater profits and business expansion. Lilian hopes that in the future, she will be able to expand the business. 

Lilian is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Lilian who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more fish.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick lives in Mombasa, Kenya. He is 37 years old and he is a businessman. He runs a retail shop in his neighborhood. He is married and has two children under his care. 

The way he got into the business is that he was a driver and the income that he got from the job is what he saved to start the business. 

He knew Milango through friends and now he seeks a loan to buy stock of flour, cooking oil, and rice for sale in the shop. He has a vision of running a successful wholesale business in the next five years. The income that he will raise from the business will improve his standard of living.

loans.use: to buy stocks of flour, cooking oil, and rice

loans.name: Resty

texts.en:
Resty is a 33 year old lady who is married and has three children who are aged 2, 4, and 8. 

She started her restaurant business in 2007 and has been running it since then. It is sometimes rather challenging due to increased competition. Right now she would like to get a loan of 1,000,000 UGX to buy a little more furniture for the place. She would love to see her working capital increase to a level where she can be self sustainable.

In the photograph are Resty and the loan officer(left to right). In the country side especially the small trading centers, our people usually do not differentiate a restaurant and hotel, so, they usually refer to them as hotels even when they are restaurants.

loans.use: To buy furniture for her restaurant

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy roofing materials for his residential house.

loans.name: Kerotai B Group

texts.en:
The Kerotai B of Nuru International consists of three farmers. It is based within Kuria West District. The members of the group came together in order to grow socially and economically through agriculture.

Zacharia, who is raising his hand in the picture, is 23 years old, married, and has two children, one of whom attends school. He has been a member of this group since 2008. He is very excited about the 2014 long rains and he hopes to implement better farming methods to increase the farm yields.  

Zacharia is requesting a loan, which he will use to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to grow maize, millet, and sorghum on his one-acre farm. He is optimistic that he will obtain enough food from the yields and sell the surplus to invest in a shop business.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to grow maize, sorghum, and millet

loans.name: Nyabahegere Group

texts.en:
Nyabahengere is a Nuru International group of three farmers in Kuria West District in Kenya. The members joined the group to acquire skills and knowledge on improved farming methods. They are able to obtain loans through Nuru to acquire farm inputs. As a group, the members of Nyabahengere collectively guarantee the loan.

Eunice, who is raising up her hand, is the chairperson of the group and has been a member of the group since the year 2009. She is 53 years old and is married with five children, three of whom are in college.
 
The loan from Kiva will enable Eunice to acquire hybrid seeds and fertilizer which will enable her to obtain high yields. Just like the other members of her group, Eunice will take input loans for one acre. She plans to grow maize on 1/2 acre and sorghum and millet on ¼ acre each. Eunice plans to sell the surplus and join a saving and loaning scheme so she will save some of the money obtained from selling the surplus. She will then obtain a loan to invest in a business and contribute to paying school fees for her children in college.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to grow maize, sorghum and millet.

loans.name: Umoja Group

texts.en:
These four farmers pictured are part of Nuru International group of farmers called Umoja. They came together in order to grow socially and economically through agriculture.

Samuel (shown with his hand raised) is 31 years old. He is married with two children. He depends solely on farming to earn a living and is therefore keen on practicing better farming methods. During the 2014 long rains, Samuel will plant a one acre farm with maize in ½ acre and sorghum and millet in ¼ acre each.

He is therefore requesting a loan to enable him to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer. With the farm inputs, he is hopeful that the harvest will be good and he will have enough food for his family. He will sell the surplus and invest in a shop business.

loans.use: To purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to grow maize, sorghum and millet

loans.name: Fig Plus Light Group

texts.en:
This group is part of Nuru International group of six farmers called Fig Plus Light, based within Kuria West District. The members of the group came together in order to grow socially and economically through agriculture. Francis, raising up his hand, has been a member of this group for two years now. He is 24 years old and married with two children.

With the loan from Kiva, Francis plans to buy hybrid seeds and fertilizer to grow maize, sorghum and millet on a one acre farm. The harvest which he hopes will be very good will provide food security for his household. He plans to sell the surplus and invest the money in a business to increase the family’s income.

loans.use: To purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to grow maize, sorghum and millet.

loans.name: Olinda

texts.en: A $1,000 loan is offered to Olinda to improve her business. She opened her kiosk in 2007 through her own work. She will use the loan to buy stock to keep in her store like women's shoes, sport shoes, clothes brushes, hair ties and pillows. She generates a good income from selling. She has been thinking of running a big business after years of involving herself in doing business. She is living in town with her family.

loans.use: To buy women's shoes, sport shoes, clothes brushes, hair ties and pillows

loans.name: Cherry

texts.en:
Cherry is a married woman and a very hard working entrepreneur. She is 34 years old and has three children who are in school.

Cherry has a vegetable vending business in the Philippines. She requested a 6,000 PHP loan through NWTF to purchase more vegetables to sell in her vegetable stall.

Cherry has been in this business for one year. In the future, Cherry would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to purchase more vegetables to sell in her vegetable stall.

loans.name: Gorret

texts.en: Gorret  is married with three children and only one of her children goes to school. She doesn’t take care of additional family members. She has a business selling green bananas and has been in this business for 20 years.  She has applied for a loan of 1,500,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy more bunches of green bananas.  She works at the market and works seven days out of every week and sells on a retail basis. Her major business challenges include seasonality and defaulters. She aspires to become a wholesaler and also to buy a plot of land and build her own house. She decided to join MCDT-SACCO because of the low interest charged. She resides in a rented house and the family has access to electricity but not to piped water. Her monthly expenses include rent and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bunches of green bananas.

loans.name: Maame Esi

texts.en:
Even though Maame Esi grew up in poverty without an education, this has not stopped her from fulfilling her dream of achieving a better life for her and her family. Currently, she is a petty trader. She prepares and sells fried fish and kenkey (a traditional Ghanaian dish made from corn dough wrapped in banana leaves) for a living. She primarily sells her kenkey in Cape Coast. Her business enterprise has grown substantially since she began five years ago. She uses the income from her business to help her husband raise their seven children. 

Maame Esi has identified that there is growing demand among consumers for her kenkey. Nevertheless, she is unable to meet their needs due to a limited inventory capacity. Thus, she aims to use her loan to purchase a greater quantity of maize and fish, therefore helping her to prepare more of her tasty kenkey and fish. With the new profits from her expanded business, Maame Esi wants to buck the trend by ensuring that all her children will be given the opportunity to further distance their family from poverty.

loans.use: to purchase a greater quantity of maize and fish, therefore helping her to prepare more of her tasty kenkey and fish.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Although she has received no prior formal education, Ekua is a petty trader. She specializes in preparing and selling kenkey (a traditional Ghanaian dish made from corn dough and wrapped in banana leaves). She usually sells her kenkey in Cape Coast. She has been involved in preparing and selling kenkey for three years. 

Ekua is married and has three children. Her husband works as a teacher. The proceeds from her business normally go toward helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and paying their children’s school fees. 

She wants to use her loan to purchase a greater quantity of maize, thus increasing her current inventory levels. As a result, this will allow her to sell greater quantities of her tasty kenkey. In the long term, Ekua plans to reinvest the future profits back into her business, thus helping her expand and meet the needs of rising customer demand.

loans.use: to purchase a greater quantity of maize, thus increasing her current inventory levels.

loans.name: Isatu

texts.en:
Meet Isatu. She is a 28-year-old from Jui, eastern area, in Freetown. She is widowed with three children. For the past three years, Isatu has established her general stock business. She began her business because she wanted to sustain her family's standard of living. She works at the business from 8:00 a.m. until 7:00 p.m., seven days per week. She says that the main challenge to her business is insufficient capital to expand her business.

Isatu requires a loan in order to purchase variety of items including cigarettes, soap, drinks and cooking seasoning to expand her business. She hopes that the extra income from this loan will allow her to become successful and increase her business. In the future, Isatu plans to build a house. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to purchase variety of items including cigarettes, soap, drinks and cooking seasoning to expand her business.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is a married woman with three children.  She is 47 years old and has one child who is still in school.  Teresita is a very hard working entrepreneur.
She has a handicraft business in the Philippines. Teresita has requested a PHP 5,000 loan amount through NWTF to purchase additional materials like shells, etc. for her business. Teresita has been in this business for 10 years. She would like to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional materials like shells, etc. for her business.

loans.name: Manasse's Group

texts.en:
Manasse’s Group has seven group farmers and is located in Webuye District. The group leaders in this group represent a total of 68 individual farmers (not pictured) who are each asking for an average loan of KES 5,349 (shillings) to purchase a One Acre Fund package for ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet. As the Kiva group representative, Manasse is pictured on the right of the group, with his hand raised.							

Manasse is married and he has eight children. He is 68 years old and is known as friendly, hard-working, reliable, trustworthy, and an experienced farmer. He is active in his community, in groups such as the men's group, savings group, prayer group, and burial committee. Manasse has been a farmer for 30 years. He described his harvest as good last year, but believes he can have an even better one this year, by continuing to work with One Acre Fund.  							

Manasse joined One Acre Fund in 2012 and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2014 season as a group leader. He joined One Acre Fund, so that he could get the best seed prices, get new farming methods, get fertilizer and hybrid seeds, and earn enough money to feed his family and send his children to school. 

Because he likes being a leader and is an active community member who wants to help more farmers and spread the story about One Acre Fund farmers, Manasse has gotten more involved with One Acre Fund, as a group leader and Kiva representative. Working with One Acre Fund has improved Manasse's life because he has more profits from harvest, has more farm training, has more farm group support, and was able to save money and feed the family.  

In the future, Manasse hopes that his profits from 2014 can be used to send his children to school, repair the home, save for the future, buy a cow, buy a goat, and invest in a business.  

Manasse's Group needs a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund. One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers through the profits from the farmers’ harvests. 

One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings to the farmers. Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund. With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits, and improved lives.	

The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Viviana Victoria

texts.es:
Viviana es una mujer de 39 años, vive en la ciudad de Pucallpa con sus cuatro hijos, ella es madre soltera, trabajadora, que dedica todos sus esfuerzos por sacar adelante a su familia; lamentablemente por falta de recursos económicos y por la necesidad de trabajar, Viviana no pudo estudiar una carrera profesional.
Por iniciativa propia, Viviana trabaja como vendedora en una empresa comercial de su ciudad, ella trabaja todos los días por un aproximado de 10 horas y cree que le va bien por su dedicación y buen desempeño.
Viviana se encuentra muy agradecida con los prestamistas Kiva, ya que gracias a la ayuda brindada realizara el mejoramiento de su vivienda, ya que desea reforzar el techado y ponerle piso de concreto a su hogar, de esta manera ella y su familia tendrán mayor seguridad y bienestar, así pues Viviana seguirá trabajando y esforzándose para lograr su gran sueño de tener una vivienda adecuada y segura para sus hijos.
texts.en:
Viviana is a 39 year-old woman, she lives in the city of Pucallpa with her four children. She is a single mother, hardworking, who dedicates all of her energy to getting her family ahead. Unfortunately, for lack of economic resources and for the need to work, Viviana could not study a professional career.

By her own initiative, Viviana works as a salesperson in a commercial business in her city. She works every day for approximately 10 hours and believes that it's going well because of her dedication and good effort.

Viviana is very thankful for the Kiva lenders, since thanks to the help they give she will carry out improvements on her home. She wishes to reinforce the roof and put a concrete floor in her home. In this manner, she and her family will have better security and wellbeing. Thus Viviana will continue working and pushing herself to achieve her great dream of having an adequate home and security for her children.

loans.use: for improving her home

loans.name: Seruni Ii Group

texts.en:
Due to the number of members of Seruni 1 and to better facilitate coordination, the group formed Seruni 2 . This Kleompok (group), newly formed earlier this month, is the same as the one that began with Seruni. The members see each other, visit each other and both groups have small businesses. There are so many types of businesses among the group members. " Seruni 2 " members are producing soybeans, selling herbs and scrubs, selling airtime credits, selling snacks or crafts, providing a place to have a drink, or selling rice Rames dishes.

Rejemiati is the leader of this group, having a business producing soybeans  which are then sent to the traditional markets near her house . Her husband helps  Rejemiati to produce soybeans. With this loan, she wants  to buy and equip her business with better tools, in order to have better production and work smoothly. She dreams of the future later on, when she wants to be a big distributor in the Cilacap region. 

Hopefully this loan from Kiva will help develop the businesses of all group members. They are very grateful to Kiva lenders, who have been helping all the members of the group, although they do not personally know them.

loans.use: to  equip her business with better tools

loans.name: Seruni I Group

texts.en:
The "Seruni" group was newly formed about one year ago. This group was formed because all the women had small businesses and knew each other. They have a common goal to further grow their businesses and improve the welfare of their families. 

There are so many types of businesses from the Seruni group, such as a bridal salon, selling herbs, selling cell phone credit, selling snacks, selling clothes and pillows, selling noodles and farming ducks and chickens.

Siti, as the leader of this group, has a bridal salon. Her husband works as a contractor. Siti has two children who are still in school. With this loan, she wants to buy equipment and bridal makeup. Currently, she rents equipment, but with this loan she won’t have to. So, the price that she charges clients will decrease, making her business more competitive. Her dream is to start a bridal course at her salon. 

This loan from Kiva will help develop the businesses of this group. Siti is very grateful to the lenders of Kiva who have helped all members of the group, even though the lenders don’t even know the members personally.

loans.use: to buy equipment and bridal makeup.

loans.name: Kuinyunyi B Group

texts.en:
Kuinyunyi B is a Nuru International group of two farmers in Kuria West District in Kenya. The members joined the group to acquire knowledge and skills in improved farming methods. They are able to obtain loans through Nuru to acquire farm inputs. As a group, the members of Kuinyunyi B collectively guarantee the loan.

Samson (pictured with the hand raised) is a representative of the group. He is 29 years old and is married with four children, three of whom go to school. He has been a member of this group since 2012. The Kiva loan in this coming season will enable him obtain hybrid seeds and fertilizer which he believes will increase his farm yields. Samson, just like other members of his group, will take input loans for one acre. He will grow maize in 1/2 acre, and sorghum and millet in a ¼ acre each. He will obtain food for his household as well as sell the surplus and contribute to the school fees for his children.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to grow maize, sorghum and millet.

loans.name: Matare Nuru Group

texts.en:
This group of three farmers is called Matare Nuru. It is a group of Nuru International farmers and is based within Kuria West District. The members of the group came together in order to grow socially and economically through agriculture.

Meremo, 33 years old, is married and has two children, and one of the children goes to school. She has been a member of this group since 2012. She is the one raising her hand in the picture. She is very excited about the 2014 long rains and she hopes to implement better farming methods to increase the farm yields. It is for this reason that Meremo is asking for a loan. She intends to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to be used in her one acre farm to grow maize, millet and sorghum. She is optimistic that she will obtain enough food from the yields and sell the surplus to invest in a shop business.

loans.use: To purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizer to grow maize, sorghum and millet.

loans.name: Wycliffe's Group

texts.en:
This is a group of 4 group leader farmers in Chwele District with Wycliffe selected as the Kiva representative.  Each of these group leader farmers represent a group of several farmers in their area.  Wycliffe has volunteered to be the Kiva group representative and is on the right of the photo with his hand raised.  Farming inputs will be delivered to him and the 52 other individual farmers represented in this group.  The credit consists of the necessary materials to plant ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of millet or sorghum.  The individual farmers are not pictured here but will be receiving an average loan of 5,349 shillings.

Wycliffe is 60 years old and has been a farmer for 30 years.  Wycliffe works as a farmer to provide for his 12 children.  The community and other farmers know Wycliffe as friendly, hardworking, reliable, trustworthy and an experienced farmer.  Other than farming, he is also involved in community activities such as the men's group, savings group, prayer group and burial committee.  Wycliffe described his harvest last year as excellent, but hopes he can have an even better one with the support of One Acre Fund and the other farmers in his group.
							
Wycliffe joined One Acre Fund in 2011, and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2014 season as a group leader.  Wycliffe joined One Acre Fund so that he could get the best seed prices, learn new farming methods, purchase fertilizer and hybrid seeds, earn enough to feed his family and send his children to school.  Because he is an active community member, he wants to help more farmers and spread the story about One Acre Fund.  Wycliffe has become more involved with One Acre Fund as a group leader and Kiva representative.  Working with One Acre Fund has improved Wycliffe's life because he has earned profits from harvest, has received more farm training, has more farm group support, been able to save money and feed the family.  In the future, Wycliffe hopes that his profits from 2014 harvests can be used to send his children to school, repair the home, save for the future, buy a cow, and invest in a business. 

One Acre Fund focuses on working with smallholder farmers across Kenya.  The organization pre-purchases seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings onto the farmers.  Wycliffe and his group will use the Kiva loan to cover this initial cost of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer package from One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund will continue to provide training and support throughout the planting and harvesting season to ensure a good harvest and repayment.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.	
						
The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: to allow farmers the opportunity to buy  maize, millet, and sorghum seeds at reduced prices.

loans.name: Maxime

texts.en:
See Maxime at work: http://youtu.be/iYslpYCtVNo

Maxime is a solar lamp distributor in Mali. He is 46 years old, married and has three children. His background is agricultural engineering.

Maxime distributes solar lamps in five regions in Mali, including Kayes, Koulikoro, Sikasso, Segou and Mopti. He sells the majority of his solar lamps to poor rural populations such as miners, rice and grain farmers, women who produce cashews, shea butter and pepper, and students. Maxime partners with local cooperatives, teachers, and a network of nuns who live in rural communities to help organize events and raise awareness about the benefits of solar lamps. He also sells through two community associations: Eau Vive Mali and GASE Yeelen, where he serves as president.

Maxime’s customers currently rely on kerosene lamps and flashlights for light. Those that have mobile phones have to walk long distances and pay to charge their phone. They spend about $110 per year on kerosene and mobile phone charging. 

However, a solar lamp that provides 8 hours of high quality light a night and can charge a mobile phone costs just $25 and has a lifetime of about five years. There are no recurring costs as sunlight powers the lamp for free! 

Paying $25 up front for a solar lamp is difficult for Maxime’s customers, though. It is challenging to save that amount of money or to obtain a small, affordable loan.  Most of Maxime's customers earn about $2 a day, which barely covers basic needs like food. Banks only lend to people with a bank account and formal employment contracts, and microfinance institutions only make loans for business activities.

A Kiva loan will allow Maxime to purchase 2,000 solar lamps from NOTS Lampe Solaire on credit and then offer credit to his customers. Ultimately, this loan will enable Maxime to improve the livelihoods of about 10,000 people and reduce the negative impact of kerosene on the environment. Families save money on light and mobile phone charging, feel safer at night, are healthier (no toxic smoke from kerosene) and can increase their income because they are able to work at night. Children are also able to study longer. A win-win-win for everyone.

loans.use: to pay for solar lamps that he will sell on credit in rural communities.

loans.name: Tamara Group

texts.es: Este grupo lo conforman cuatro mujeres emprendedoras y luchadoras una de ellas es Josefa tiene la edad de 32 años, casada, con un hijo de 9 años de edad, su negocio es la venta de ropa usada y de cosméticos de Avon, tiene de ser cliente de la institución 4 años. El crédito lo solicita para diversificar su actividad economica  en   la compra de ropa nueva como pantalones, camisas, blusas, shores, trajecitos de niños, etc. María Alejandra tiene 42 años su negocio es la venta de productos ferreteros y librería, Julia Marcelina tiene 65 años su negocio es la venta de comida  y Johana tiene 38 años de edad su negocio es la venta de ropa usada.
texts.en:
This group is made up of four determined entrepreneurial women. One of them is Josefa who is 32 years old and is married with a 9-year-old son. She has a business selling used clothing and Avon cosmetics. She has been a client of the institution for 4 years.

Josefa is asking for the loan to diversify her income generating activity by buying new clothing such as trousers, shirts, blouses, shorts, children's clothing etc.

María Alejandra is 42 years old and has a business selling hardware and stationery; Julia Marcelina is 65 and has a business selling food and Johana who is 38 has a business selling used clothing.

loans.use: to buy new clothing such as trousers, shirts, blouses, shorts, children's clothing etc.

loans.name: Rios De Agua Viva Group

texts.es: Este grupo lo forman cuatro socias de negocio una de ellas es Zoila mujer de 38 años de edad, soltera, con un hija bajo su cargo de 12 años, su negocio es la venta de bisutería y ropa desde hace 16 años, su mama y ella se encargan del negocio, tiene de ser cliente de la institución 8 años. El crédito lo requiere para la compra de pantalones de varón, de mujer, camisas, blusas, shores, chapas, collares, anillos, cadenas,  prensadores, pulseras, aros, colas, etc.  Marlene tiene 55 años es comerciante de bisutería, Jeanette tiene 40 años se dedica a vender bisutería y Eufemia tiene  su negocio  como es la venta de bisutería.
texts.en:
The members of this group are four businesswomen. One of them is Zoila who is 38 years old and is single, with a dependent 12-year-old daughter. For 16 years she has had a business selling jewelry and clothing. She and her mum run the business and she has been a client of the institution for 8 years.

Zoila needs the loan to buy men's and women's trousers, shirts, blouses, shorts, badges, necklaces, rings, chains, hair accessories, bracelets, earrings etc.

Marlene is 55 years old and sells jewelry. Jeanette is 40 and makes a living selling jewelry and Eufemia also sells jewelry.

loans.use: to buy men's and women's trousers, shirts, blouses, shorts, badges, necklaces, rings, chains, hair accessories, bracelets, earrings etc.

loans.name: Mmasava's Group

texts.en:
Mmasava’s group has four group leader farmers and is located in Webuye District.
