The group leaders represent a total of 57 individual farmers (not pictured) who are each asking for an average loan of 5,349 KES to purchase a One Acre Fund package for ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of sorghum or millet.  As the Kiva group representative, Mmasava is pictured on the right of the Bahati Group with his hand raised.
							
Mmasava is a reliable member of the community.  He is married with three children.  Mmasava is 38 years old and has been working as a farmer for the last 20 years to support his family.  In addition to this, Mmasava is very active in his community and is involved in the savings group and prayer group.  His harvest last year was not with One Acre Fund.  He hopes as a One Acre Fund farmer, he will be able to join the ranks of the One Acre Fund farmers that have doubled their harvest in their first year of the program!							
							
The 2013 Long Rains season will be Mmasava’s first season with One Acre Fund.  He joined this year in order to learn new farming methods.  As an active member in his community,  Mmasava also volunteered his time to be a group leader and Kiva representative because he wants to help more farmers.  Mmasava plans on using profits from the harvest to save for the future.  He believes that his life will improve by working with One Acre Fund.
							
Mmasava and the Bahati Group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund.   One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers through the profits from the farmers’ harvests.  One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings to the farmers.  Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.
							
The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and hybrid seeds for maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Gabriela Martinez

texts.es: Gabriela de 55 años de edad vive junto a su familia en casa propia; Ella posee un chalet donde vende artículos de primera necesidad tiene varios años con el negocio, tiene mucha clientela porque vende productos de primera calidad a precios bajos, y es muy amable; ella quiere invertir en su negocio comprando mas productos para surtir su tienda por eso solicita un crédito que le permita comprar  granos básicos, golosinas, pan, huevos productos instantáneos, bebidas etc. ella es muy responsable, asegura que podrá saldar la deuda y a la vez tiene la esperanza que de esta forma podrá darle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en: Gabriela is 55 years old and lives with her family in her own home. She has a stand where she sells essential items such as bread, beans, rice, milk, eggs, and lunch meat, among others. She has been in business several years and gained valuable experience that has allowed her to earn a higher profit. She has many customers because she sells quality products at low prices and she is very friendly. She wants to invest in her business, buying more products to supply her store. She is asking for a loan in order to buy basic grains, snacks, bread, eggs, instant products, drinks, etc. Gabriela has good payment references and is very responsible. She says that she can pay her debt and at the same time she hopes that this will allow her to be able to give her family a better quality of life.

loans.use: to purchase basic grains, snacks, bread, eggs, instant products, drinks, etc.

loans.name: Rosemary's Group

texts.en:
Rosemary’s group has six farmers, each of whom is a group leader for several other farmers. They are located in Kakamega North District.  The group leaders in this group represent a total of 52 individual farmers (not pictured). Each of the farmers is asking for an average loan of 5,349 Kenya shillings. Each of them will use his or her loan to purchase a One Acre Fund package, sufficient to cultivate one-quarter acre of maize and one-quarter acre of sorghum or millet.

As the representative of this Kiva group comprised of farmer-leaders, Rosemary is pictured on the right of the group with her hand raised.  Rosemary is a reliable member of the community.  She is married and has two children.  She is 56 years old, and she has been working as a farmer for the past 21 years to support her family.  In addition to this, Rosemary is very active in her community, including involvement in the women's group and savings group.  The 2013 Long Rains season won’t be Rosemary’s first season with One Acre Fund.  She first joined One Acre Fund in 2011.  She has continued working with One Acre Fund, in order to get the best seed prices, to learn new farming methods, and to get fertilizer and hybrid seeds.  She described her harvest last year as "Good."  She hopes to continue working with One Acre Fund and to continue enjoying the success she has been having with the One Acre Fund farm packages. 

As an active member in her community, Rosemary also chose to be a group leader and Kiva representative, because she wants to help more farmers.  Rosemary plans on using future profits from the harvest to send children to school and to save for the future.  She has improved her life by working with One Acre Fund, because she has more farm training and she is able to feed the family. 

Rosemary and her group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund will repay the Kiva loan on behalf of the farmers, with the profits from the farmers’ harvests.  One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings along to the farmers.  Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.

The field officer is included in the photo with the farmer-leaders, and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Leh We Try Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the Leh We Try group from Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva.org to apply for a loan of 500,000.00 Sierra Leonean Leones (SLL) each. With the help of this loan, they will be able to expand their respective businesses, make more sales, and consequently improve upon their living conditions. 

Isata is the featured leader of this group. The 35-year-old is married to a trader and they have four children. Isata has been a businesswoman for many years now; she sells market food – rice, margi (used to give sauce a sweet taste), tomatoes, etc. With her share of this loan, she will buy the above-mentioned items in wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.use: to buy rice, margi, tomatoes, etc. in wholesale to add to her current stock.

loans.name: Ropolon Group

texts.en:
Veronica is the featured leader of this group of entrepreneurs. Veronica was born in Tonkolili district in northern Sierra Leone 42 years ago. She is married to a trader. The couple has six children who are attending primary and secondary schools. Veronica sells cosmetics and has been doing business for many years now. 

With the help of this loan, Veronica and her group members will be able to expand their respective businesses, make more sales and consequently improve on their living conditions. Veronica will use her share of the loan (500,000 SLL) to buy a wide variety of cosmetics to add to her current inventory.

loans.use: to buy a wide variety of cosmetics to add to her current inventory

loans.name: Grace's Group

texts.en:
This group consists of five group leader of farmers in Kakamega North district, with Grace selected as the Kiva representative. Grace has volunteered to be the Kiva's group representative, and is on the right of the photo with her hand raised. Farming inputs will be delivered to her and the 56 other individual farmers represented in this group. The credit consists of the necessary materials to plant ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of millet or sorghum.  The individual farmers are not pictured here, but will be receiving an average loan of 5,349 shillings.
							
Grace is a reliable member of the community. She is married with nine children. Grace is 53 years old and has been working as a farmer for the last two years to support her family. In addition to this, Grace is very active in her community and involved in the women's group and savings group. She described her harvest last year as excellent. She hopes as a One Acre Fund farmer, to be able to join the ranks of One Acre Fund farmers who have doubled their harvest in their first year of the program!

Grace joined One Acre Fund in 2012, and is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2014 season as a group leader. Grace joined One Acre Fund so that she can get the best seed prices, new farming methods, and fertilizer and hybrid seeds, and earn enough to feed her family. Because she likes being a leader and an active community member, she wants to help more farmers and spread the story about One Acre Fund farmers. Grace has gotten more involved with One Acre Fund as a group leader and Kiva's representative. Working with One Acre Fund has improved Grace's life because she has more profits from harvest and more farm group support, and was able to save money and feed the family. In the future, Grace hopes that her profits from 2014 can be used to send children to school, save for the future, and invest in a business.
  							
Grace and her group need a loan to cover the initial costs of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer through One Acre Fund. One Acre Fund will repay Kiva's loan on behalf of the farmers through the profits from the farmers’ harvests. One Acre Fund pre-purchases the seeds and fertilizers when prices are low and passes the cost savings to the farmers. Throughout the planting and harvesting season, One Acre Fund also provides training and support to the farmers as they make payments back to One Acre Fund. With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits, and improved lives.
							
The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seeds and fertilizers for harvesting maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Alhaji

texts.en:
This is 31-year-old Alhaji, who is married, with two children aged six and three. He has four additional dependents, who live with him for business and school. 

In 2002, Alhaji established his Provisions business. He began his business to better his standard of living. His business is located in the city centre and his customers are both men and women. Working seven days a week and 11 hours a day, he earns about 1,500,000 SLL every month from this business. 

He is requesting a loan of 5,000,000 SLL. Alhaji has already received and successfully repaid two loans, and now requires a new loan in order to buy 1,000,000 sardines, 1,000,000 tins of Peak milk, and 1,500,000 bond street cigarettes. 

He hopes that this loan will increase his increase his profit. In the future, Alhaji plans to complete the construction of his house and rent a space in his shop. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy sardines, Peak milk and bond stick cigarettes

loans.name: Samai

texts.en:
This is 55-year-old Samai. He is Married and has six children, ages 33, 31, 27,19, 11 and 8. He has five additional dependents who live with him as his apprentices. In 1985, Samai established his tailoring business. He began his business because he wanted to engage himself in income generating activity. His business is located at a city center, and his main customers are all classes of customers. 

Working seven days a week and 16 hours a day, he earns about SLL 500,000 every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of SLL 3,000,000. Samai has already received, and successfully repaid, one loan, and now requires a new loan in order to buy sewing inputs. 

He hopes that this loan shall enable him to buy more inputs for his workshop. In the future, Samai plans to build a house and educate his children. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to pay for sewing inputs.

loans.name: Osinatu

texts.en:
This is 50-year-old Osinatu. She is married and has two children, ages 19 and 15. In 1994, Osinatu established her clothing and textiles business. She began her business just to generate enough funds to support her children. Her business is located at a city center, and her main customers are mostly women. 

Working seven days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about SLL 780,000 every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 5,000,000. Osinatu has already received and successfully repaid 3 loans, and now requires a new loan in order to buy window curtain, wax Cotton, simple lace, and dry cotton material. 

She hopes that this loan shall increase her stock and profit level. In the future, Osinatu plans to educate her children, develop her plot of land, and rent a shop. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy window curtain, wax Cotton, simple lace, and dry cotton material

loans.name: Leyla Vicenta

texts.es:
María es una mujer ejemplar de profesión maestra de educación primaria, actualmente se desempeña como bibliotecaria en un colegio de la localidad donde vive, se  ha destacado por la atención y apoyo que le brinda a los estudiantes, es casada con 1 hijo al que está apoyando para sus estudios técnicos, su esposo tiene un pequeño taller de ebanistería como otra alternativa económica, 
Esta señora quiere mejorar su vivienda por eso visito ceprodel para solicitar financiamiento y realizar un Repello a las paredes, ya que el mismo lo utilizara en la  
 Compra de materiales de construcción como: cemento, piedrín, arena y mano de obra, el que le vendría a dar mejores condiciones  a su familia.
texts.en:
María es una mujer ejemplar de profesión maestra de educación primaria, actualmente se desempeña como bibliotecaria en un colegio de la localidad donde vive, se  ha destacado por la atención y apoyo que le brinda a los estudiantes, es casada con 1 hijo al que está apoyando para sus estudios técnicos, su esposo tiene un pequeño taller de ebanistería como otra alternativa económica, 
Esta señora quiere mejorar su vivienda por eso visito ceprodel para solicitar financiamiento y realizar un Repello a las paredes, ya que el mismo lo utilizara en la  
 Compra de materiales de construcción como: cemento, piedrín, arena y mano de obra, el que le vendría a dar mejores condiciones  a su familia.

loans.use: to buy construction materials such as perlin beams, zinc, metal tubes, gravel, sand, bolts, cement, iron, blocks, and wire.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
Meet James, a farmer living in the Nyamira area of Kenya. He has been farming for 2 years where he produces and sells milk, and tea. He loves dairy farming the most because his cows produce a lot of milk for sale,but his biggest challenge is insufficient funds for carrying out farming.
James chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan because they have a low interest rate on their loans. During the training,he learned how to develop a lifestyle of saving and that Juhudi Kilimo helps small holder farmers to expand economically. James says that this loan will help him build a good life for his future family.

loans.use: to purchase poultry.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Although she has received no prior formal education, Esther is an entrepreneur. She specializes in selling provisions in Besease (near Elmina). She has been involved in this enterprise for more than ten years.Esther is married and has five children.Her husband works as a farmer. The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and pay their children’s school fees. Esther wants to use her loan to increase her current inventory levels, hence allowing her to sell greater quantities of groceries. In the long term, Esther plans to reinvest future profits into her business, thus helping her expand and meet the needs of rising customer demands.

loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels

loans.name: Saidu

texts.en:
This is 52-year-old Saidu. He is married and has five children; the oldest four are 13, 9, 6, and 3 years old and the baby is now about two year old. 

In 1996, Saidu established his business, selling jeans, Lacoste, Polo, school bags, crepes, shoes, etc. Working seven days a week and 10 hours a day, he earns about 2,100,000 SLL every month from this business.  He would like a loan of 4,500,000 SLL. Saidu has already received and successfully repaid two loans and now requires a new loan in order to buy jeans, crepe and Polo.

Saidu has completed building a dwelling house for his family. He also used part of the profit from his last loan to pay school charges for his children. In the future, Saidu plans to continue supporting his children’s education and keep improving his business. This loan will help him to maximize profit. Saidu is trustworthy and hardworking. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy jeans, crepe and polo

loans.name: Ta-Yokaneh Atima Group

texts.en:
Meet the members of the Ta-Yokaneh Atima group from Magburaka, a town in northern Sierra Leone. They are all local entrepreneurs who have come to SMT, a partner of Kiva, to apply for a loan of 500,000 Sierra Leonean Leones (SLL) each. With the help of this loan they will be able to expand their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their living conditions. 

Fatmata is the featured leader of this group. The 49-year-old is married to a trader and they have seven children, who attend schools. Fatmata has been a businesswoman for many years now; she sells palm oil (the country’s most popular cooking oil). With her share of this loan, she is going to buy gallons of palm oil to add to her current stock. 

(Also included in the right of the photo is loan officer Gibrill, posing with the borrowers).

loans.use: to buy gallons of palm oil to add to her current stock

loans.name: Bilkisu

texts.en:
This is 43-year-old Bilkisu. She is divorced and has two children, aged 25 and 21 years. Both of them are school-going. She has two additional dependents, who live with her to be fostered. In 1993, Bilkisu established her jeans business, buying and reselling jeans, travelling boxes, Bamako cloth, sets of pans and dishes, bowls, wax cotton, and other items. She began her business because she had dropped out of school and decided to join her mother in petty trading. When she got married, her husband gave her some amount of money to start up a business. Working 7 days a week and 11 hours a day, she earns about Le 1,400,000 every month from this business.

At this time, she would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,500,000. Bilkisu requires a loan in order to buy jeans, travelling boxes, Bamako cloth, etcetera.

Bilkisu did not yet meet her goals (mentioned in her previous loan description), for her to open a shop and to complete her house, because she lost her 25-year-old daughter. Bilkisu is a hardworking businesswoman. She thanks you for supporting businesswomen in Sierra Leone, and she thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy jeans, travelling boxes, Bamako cloth, etcetera.

loans.name: Jessica Aracely

texts.es:
Jessica Aracely tiene 33 años de edad vive junto a su hijo y esposo en el distrito de Ucupe, una comunidad dedica al comercio, agricultura y crianza de animales menores.

Ella se dedica a la venta de abarrotes desde hace tres años, su negocio se encuentra ubicado en su domicilio, ha solicitado un préstamo de 1 000 nuevos soles para la compra de mercadería arroz, aceite, leche, menestras entre otros, para abastecer su negocio y de esta manera generar mayores ingresos para su familia.
texts.en:
Jessica Aracely, 33, lives with her son and her husband in the District of Ucupe, a community working in commerce, agriculture and raising small animals. She has been selling groceries for three years. Her business is located in her house. 

She is requesting a loan of 1,000 Peruvian Nuevos Soles to purchase supplies such as rice, oil, milk, pulse (grain legumes) among other items to stock her business and this way generate better revenue for her family.

loans.use: to purchase rice, oil, milk, pulse (grain legumes) to supply her shop.

loans.name: Lorenzo Agapo

texts.es:
Lorenzo un hombre trabajador de 58 años de edad el mantiene una relación en unión libre con Norma con la que tuvo 6 hijos de los cuales 2 aún viven en casa con ellos. Él vive y trabaja en el l Cantón San Miguel de los Bancos en un pequeño recinto llamado Guadalupe es un lugar muy hermoso y tranquilo es un recinto muy conocido por la gran cantidad de ganaderos que existe uno de ellos es Don Lorenzo que se dedica al negocio del ganado lechero conoce mucho de esta actividad, desde muy niño aprendió con sus padres ya que ellos tenían una finca ganadera. Trabaja un promedio de 8 a 10 horas diarias por lo que no le queda mucho tiempo libre, a Don Lorenzo le gusta hacer deporte y aprovechando que en casa tienen una cancha para realizarlo con frecuencia en las tardes 
Este negocio no es muy complicado pero en ocasiones las vacas se enferman y se les dificulta un poco porque tienen que salir al pueblo a buscar un veterinario quien les ayude 
Don Lorenzo tiene muchos sueños que quisiera realizar uno de ellos es incrementar su producción de leche comprando mas vacas y también le gustaría comprar ganado para carne, este préstamo ayudara a don Lorenzo a mejorar su calidad de vida he ingresos ya que se lo invertirá en un negocio muy rentable del cual tiene mucho conocimiento, una granja de cerdos. Don Lorenzo agradece a Fundación Alternativa por el apoyo y la oportunidad que le están brindando a él y su familia de mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Lorenzo is a hard-working, 58 year old man. He lives common-law with Norma with whom he has six children. Two of them still live in their home.He lives and works in the 1st canton of San Miguel de los Bancos in a hamlet called Guadalupe. It is a beautiful and tranquil place and is known for the great quantity of people who raise livestock there.

Lorenzo is one of them and he raises milk cows and has a lot of knowledge in this field. As a youngster he learned for his parents on their cattle farm. He works on average 8 to 10 hours per day. He doesn't have much free time but he likes to play sports. They have a field at their house so he can practice there in the evenings. The business is not overly complicated but sometimes the cows get sick and he has to go to town to find a vet to help him. 

Lorenzo has a lot of dreams. One of them is to increase his milk production by buying more cows. He also would like to buy cattle for meat. This loan will help Lorenzo improve his quality of living. He will invest it in a very profitable business that he knows a lot about, which is a pig farm. Lorenzo is grateful to Fundación Alternativa for it's support and the opportunity being offered to his family to improve their quality of life.

loans.use: to buy milk cows.

loans.name: Donato

texts.en:
Donavell is 17 years old and is the fourth of 4 children in the family. Her father, Donato as a member of Project Dungganon supports the family through his motorcycle transport and pig raising business in the Philippines.

Donavell is studying for a Bachelor in Elementary Education, and is currently in the second year of this four year course.

Donavell is borrowing Php 9,871 to pay for tuition fees for the second semester of the school year 2013-14.

When she graduates, Donavell plans to be gainfully employed and help her parents to generate additional income.

loans.use: to pay for tuition fees

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en:
Ma, Mel Rose is 16 years old and is 1st of 5 children in the family. Her mother Emelia who is the member of Project Dungganon supports the family through her fish vending business in the Philippines.


Ma, Mel Rose is studying Bachelor of Science in Criminology and is currently in the 1st of this 4-year course.

Ma, Mel Rose is borrowing 4620 to pay for tuition fees of the 2nd semester of school year 2013-14.

When she graduates, Ma, Mel Rose plans to be gainfully employed and help her parents.

loans.use: to pay her tuition fees

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase three local pigs and renovate the cage

loans.name: Caren

texts.en:
Caren lives and works outside of Sindo, in Homa Bay county.  Caren is married and has seven children. She has been farming for forty years and is currently growing maize, groundnuts, lentils, beans, sunflower and amaranth. Caren likes beekeeping because it is not labor-intensive and still provides good returns.  She thinks that “beekeeping, being a new project at my old age, will change my life.” 

This is Karen’s first loan with Kiva, and she plans to use the income generated by her hives to pay school fees for her grandchildren. Her message to Kiva lenders is “thank them a lot for considering even the old.”

loans.use: To buy beehives for honey production

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is a 45-year-old married man. He has two children. He describes himself to be ambitious. He operates a retail business where he sells stationery items, such as printing papers, pens, pencils, etc. He also does printing of documents. He has been involved in this business for 10 years. His business is located in an area with potential, and his primary customers are of all types. He describes his biggest business challenge to be inadequate finances. 

He will use the KES 20,000 loan to add a stock of stationery items, such as printing papers, pens, etc. He hopes that in the future, he will be financially stable. This is his first loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to add stock of stationery items, such as printing papers, pens, etc.

texts.es:
Carmita es una mujer de 42 años, soltera, no tiene hijos. Vive en Santo Domingo de los Colorados en casa de un hermano allí tiene su local.
 Carmita hace 4 años cuenta con un bazar, además realiza manualidades para vender y por esto es muy conocida en el barrio. Cuenta con su propia casa pero como no cuenta con el espacio para su negocio no ha podido ir a habitarla y ahora la tiene arrendada. Su sueño es con sus ingresos poco a poco ir mejorándola para ponerse su propio local.  Carmita acudió a Fundación Alternativa para para nuevamente ser favorecida con un crédito, ahora necesita comprar materia prima para realizar sus manualidades por la temporada navideña ya desea surtir su negocio, ella agradece a Fundación Alternativa y a Kiva por la ayuda que le brindan para mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Carmita is 42 years old, single and has no children. She lives in Santo Domingo de los Colorados in the house of a brother. She has her store here. For four years she has run her shop. Besides this she makes handicrafts for sale and is well known in the neighborhood for this activity. She has her own house but doesn't have the room there for her shop so she does not live there and it is leased out. With her income increasing little by little her dream is to own her own shop.

Carmita has come to Fundación Alternativa to once again ask for a loan. She needs to buy raw material to make her handicrafts for the Christmas season as she wants to stock her store. She is grateful to Fundación Alternativa and Kiva for the support they offer her to improve her quality of living.

loans.use: to buy raw material to make more decorative items for the Christmas season.

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela lives and works outside of Sindo, in Homa Bay county. Homa Bay county is located at the southwestern tip of Kenya and its northern end is dominated by Lake Victoria, the largest lake in the Southern Hemisphere. 

Lake Victoria extends into three east African countries, allowing cross-border flows of goods and people and a market day in a lakeside town in Homa Bay county often boasts traders from Uganda, Tanzania, and Kenya, all of whom arrive in boats to ply their wares. 

Although the semi-arid nature of much of Homa Bay county means that poverty rates are quite high, many people in the region hold a strong cultural emphasis on education and, as a result, school attendance figures around Homa Bay are above the national average. 

Pamela is married, and has seven children, some of whom are pictured with her above. Pamela farms their land and takes care of their children and two orphans, as well. She has been farming for ten years and is currently growing cabbage, sweet potatoes, onions, maize, bananas, and sunflowers on their land. 

Pamela thinks that beekeeping is a beneficial business because bees will pollinate her sunflowers and honey has medicinal properties, as well. 

This is Pamela’s first loan with Honey Care Africa and Kiva and she plans to use the income from her hives to pay her children’s school fees and to increase her farming activities. 

In the future, Pamela hopes to see her children healthy, well-fed, and regularly attending school. She thanks her Kiva lenders and says “I would like to get in touch with them.”

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline is a widow with five children.  She is a farmer, and has been farming for ten years. She is currently growing sunflowers, beans, maize, and sweet potatoes. She is looking forward to beekeeping as it will give her an opportunity to earn extra income.

This is Jackline’s first loan with Honey Care. She intends to use the proceeds from her beekeeping to pay for her children’s school fees and to provide for their basic needs. Jackline’s hope for the future is to produce more honey for more income generation.

Jackline lives in Sindo, a small town in Homa Bay County. Homa Bay county is located in south-western Kenya, close both the Tanzanian border and Lake Victoria, Africa's largest lake. Despite the proximity to the lake, water infrastructure in Homa Bay remains quite undeveloped, and inconsistent rains and occasional droughts make life difficult for farmers in the area. Nonetheless, farmers have adapted to these challenges, particularly by diversifying their crops to include cassava, sunflower, sorghum, bananas, groundnuts, and millet, as well as drought-resistant varieties of papaya and mangoes. Although beekeeping has not traditionally been practiced in the region, many individuals have expressed interest in keeping bees and are knowledgeable about their pollination benefits.

loans.use: to buy beehives and apiary materials for honey production.

loans.name: Tiroto

texts.en:
Tiroto is a farmer living in the rich highlands of Kericho with her two children.

She has practiced farming for the past four years. She produces and sells milk, eggs, tea, and some vegetables. She really enjoys dairy farming the most because of the high milk production. Her major challenge in dairy farming is when there is lack of sufficient feed for her cattle, which makes milk production decrease.

Tiroto chose Juhudi Kilimo for this loan because they offer their loans at a low interest rate and loan repayment is easy to achieve. Tiroto says that this loan will help her purchase a chaff cutter so that she can easily get fodder for her dairy cows and therefore increase milk production. This will increase her income base and thus better her family's livelihood.

loans.use: To purchase a chaff cutter.

loans.name: Hudson's Group

texts.en:
This group consists of eight group leader farmers in Kakamega North District, with Hudson selected as the Kiva representative. Hudson has volunteered to be the Kiva group representative and is on the right of the photo with his hand raised. Farming inputs will be delivered to him and the 90 other individual farmers represented in this group. The credit consists of the necessary materials to plant one-quarter acre of maize and one-quarter acre of millet or sorghum. The individual farmers are not pictured here but will be receiving an average loan of 5,349 Kenyan shillings each.

Hudson is a reliable member of the community. He is married with eight children. Hudson is 61 years old and has been working as a farmer for the last 38 years to support his family. In addition to this, Hudson is very active in his community and is involved in the prayer group. He described his harvest last year as good. He hopes to continue working with One Acre Fund and to continue the success he is having with the One Acre Fund farm packages.							

Hudson joined One Acre Fund in 2013 and has continue working with One Acre Fund in order to get new farming methods and earn enough to feed his family. As an active member in his community, Hudson also chose to be a group leader and Kiva representative because he is an active community member who wants to spread the story about One Acre Fund farmers. Hudson plans on using future profits from the harvest to send children to school and save for the future. His life has improved by working with One Acre Fund because he has more farm group support and was able to feed the family. Hudson is also involved in the community's school committee.

One Acre Fund focuses on working with smallholder farmers across Kenya. The organization pre-purchases seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings onto the farmers. Hudson and his group will use the Kiva loan to cover this initial cost of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer package from One Acre Fund. One Acre Fund continues providing training and support throughout the planting and harvesting season to ensure a good harvest and repayment. With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.			

Please note that there is one additional group leader in this photo who will be working with One Acre Fund but will not be a part of this Kiva group loan.

The field officer is also included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: to purchase hybrid seed and fertilizer for the cultivation of maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Judith's Group

texts.en:
This group consists of 8 group leader farmers in the Kakamega North District with Judith selected as the Kiva representative.  Judith has volunteered to be the Kiva group representative and is on the right of the photo with her hand raised.  Farming inputs will be delivered to her and the 89 other individual farmers represented in this group.  The credit consists of the necessary materials to plant ¼ acre of maize and ¼ acre of millet or sorghum.  The individual farmers are not pictured here but will be receiving an average loan of 5,349 shillings.							

Judith is a reliable member of the community.  She is married with five children.  Judith is 37-years-old and has been working as a farmer for the last ten years to support her family.  In addition to this, Judith is very active in her community and is involved in the women's group and prayer group.  She hopes to continue working with One Acre Fund and to continue the success she is having with the One Acre Fund farm packages.							

Judith is now enrolling in the Long Rains 2014 season as a group leader.  Judith joined One Acre Fund so that she could get new farming methods.  Because she wants to help more farmers, and wants to spread the story about One Acre Fund farmers, Judith has gotten more involved with One Acre Fund as a group leader and Kiva representative.  In the future, Judith hopes that her profits from 2014 can be used to send her children to school and buy a cow.  							

One Acre Fund focuses on working with smallholder farmers across Kenya. The organization pre-purchases seeds and fertilizer when prices are low and passes the cost savings onto the farmers. Judith and her group will use the Kiva loan to cover this initial cost of purchasing the seeds and fertilizer package from One Acre Fund.  One Acre Fund continues providing training and support throughout the planting and harvesting season to ensure a good harvest and repayment.  With support from One Acre Fund and your loan, these farmers will have a chance at a successful harvest, increased profits and improved lives.

Please note that there are 4 additional group leaders in this photo that will be working with One Acre Fund but will not be a part of this Kiva group loan.

The field officer is included in the photo and is standing on the left of the photo.

loans.use: To provide Kenyan farmers with increased access to hybrid seeds and fertilizer for harvesting maize, millet, and sorghum.

loans.name: Ruby

texts.en:
Cheyenne her daughter is 18 years old and is the first of two children in the family. Her mother Ruby, who is the member of Project Dungganon, supports the family through her general store business in the Philippines.

Cheyenne is studying for a Bachelor of Science in Radiologic Technology and is currently in the first year of this four-year course.

Cheyenne is borrowing 10,000 PHP to pay the tuition fees for the second semester of the 2013-14 school year.

When she graduates, Cheyenne plans to finish her studies and help her parents.

loans.use: to pay for tuition fees

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
Joycel her daughter is 16 years old and is 4th of seven children in the family. Her mother Josie is a member of Project Dungganon and supports the family through her general store and buy and sell livestock business in the Philippines.


Joycel is studying Bachelor in Secondary Education and is currently in the 1st of this 4-year course.

Joycel is borrowing 6000 to pay for tuition fees of the second semester of the school year 2013-14.

When she graduates, Joycel plans to her parents and brother and sister to finish college also.

loans.use: to pay tuition fees.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is 30 years old and married. She has two children, both of whom are in school.

Helen is in the agricultural business, raising pigs in the Philippines. She has been raising pigs for two years. She requested a 6,000 PHP loan through NWTF in order to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

In the future, Helen would like to save enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Susanna

texts.en:
Susanna lives in the village of Brnakot in the Syuniq region. She lives with her husband and two adult children. Together with her husband, Susanna has been involved in agriculture for many years. Specifically, they cultivate different types of crops and sell their harvest in local open markets. Susanna and her husband do their best to assist their children and give them normal living conditions. 

The only source of family income is agriculture and, as their current financial condition doesn't allow for investment in the farm, Susanna has applied for this loan. With the loan of $3,000 USD, Susanna will be able to purchase seeds and fuel for cultivation and also hire workers for gathering the harvest. This loan will be a huge support for Susanna who is a very attentive and hard-working woman with a good credit history behind her.

loans.use: to pay for seeds and fuel for cultivation and pay for the workforce gathering the harvest.

loans.name: Siranush

texts.en: Siranush lives in the village of Lehvaz with her husband, mother-in-law, and two little kids. The whole family is engaged in agriculture and farming. Siranush's husband is a herdsman of their village and does his best to support his family. The family keeps a farm which includes cows, calves, pigs and chickens. The farm isn't a big one but they plan and desire strongly to make it larger and more profitable. That's the reason Siranush has applied for this loan. She asks for a loan of 2,900 USD to purchase two more cows, two calves, and forage for feeding the livestock. The loan will be a great assistance for this hardworking family and Susanna hopes for the lenders's trust and support.

loans.use: to pay for two cows, two calves, and forage for feeding livestock

loans.name: Hovhannes

texts.en:
Hovhannes has been involved in beekeeping. He keeps 55 colonies of bees, gathers high-quality honey and sells it locally. He lives with his parents who assist him in beekeeping. As honey is a must-have item for almost each household in Armenia, Hovhannes perfectly manages to satisfy his clients' needs.

Currently, because of financial difficulties that Hovhannes is facing, he has no means to invest in his agribusiness. By asking for this loan of $3,000 from Kiva lenders, Hovhannes wants to increase his bee colonies by 30. This will give him an opportunity to increase his income and provide a better life for his family.

Hovhannes will be very grateful to lenders and hopes for their support.

loans.use: to pay for 30 colonies of bees

loans.name: Majid

texts.en:
Majid lives in Sis village. He is a farmer with 12 years of experience. The farm that Majid currently owns consists of 5 cows and calves.  He also owns a plot of land where he cultivates potatoes, onions and greens. Majid sells the gathered harvest in the nearby market and gathers income, which is vital for his big family. 

Majid's family consists of his wife, his daughter, son, daughter-in-law and three grandchildren. The whole family helps Majid to gather a good agricultural harvest. Since that's the only source of their income, they work hard to be able to cover basic daily costs. Majid has now applied for the loan of USD 3,000 to be able to purchase more calves and forage for feeding the livestock. The loan will expand his livestock and he will be able to get more agricultural income.  Majid and his family hope for lenders' support and goodwill.

loans.use: to pay for calves and forage for feeding the livestock

loans.name: Karine

texts.en:
Karine is a teacher with many years of experience teaching at the village school. She lives with her husband, who is also a teacher, and her 25-year-old son. Together with her husband, Karine runs a farm. The farm currently includes cows, pigs, and chickens. Near the Achajour village where Karine and her family live, they also own a plot of land where different types of fruit and vegetables are cultivated. 

Due to their hard and tireless work over the years, Karine and her husband own a sustainable farm. However, currently, because of financial difficulties that they are facing, it is difficult for this couple to increase the number of livestock and enlarge their agricultural profit. Karine has applied for this loan of USD 2000 to purchase a cow and a calf. The loan will be a huge support for Karine and she is very thankful to lenders for their support.

loans.use: to pay for a cow and a calf

loans.name: Ramela

texts.en:
Ramela is from Sis village, where she lives with her husband and son. She is an agronomist with many years of experience running a farm. The farm currently includes livestock as well as an orchard with different fruit trees.

Ramela's husband sells the harvest in nearby local markets and gathers income for the family. This hard-working family is now in need of financial support to increase the farm operation that they are currently running. The loan of USD 2,500 will assist Ramela to purchase pigs, chickens, cows and forage for feeding the livestock. The loan will be a huge support for Ramela and she will be very grateful to the lenders.

loans.use: to pay for pigs, chickens, cows and forage for feeding the livestock

loans.name: Maa Tarini Shg (A) Group

texts.en:
The featured borrower of this group is Sailabala. She is pictured here;the lady standing with a raised hand. She is 37 years old and lives with her husband and three children. They live as a joint family, which means her husband’s brother and his wife also live with them and Sailabala helps take care of her husband’s parents. They are all farmers and cultivate the land near the house and sell the goods in the local village market. 

Sailabala is now requesting a loan to invest in her portion of the rice farm. She wants to buy higher quality seeds and fertilizers. She hopes this will help her earn a higher profit so she can save enough to buy more land for cultivation. She’s a little nervous about taking her first loan, but is also really excited for the opportunity to take the responsibility to help provide for her family. She wants to use the profits to have a good life for herself, as well as her family. She says, “I want to see my daughters have a good future. I expect to help them get married in a good family and for my son to become a government employee.”

The other women in her group are also engaged in farming activities and small shops. According to Sailabala, they all help one another. “If any one is at a problem, we are there for her.” 

She and her whole group say “Thank you” to Kiva for reaching out to help vulnerable women in India.

loans.use: To purchase higher quality seeds and fertilizers for her rice farming.

loans.name: Jubilee Tukore Group

texts.en:
Jubilee Tukore, a recurrent group for loans is located on the outskirts of Ibanda town. 

Saidat, a widow, used her previous loan to buy second-hand clothes to sell. She made enough profits and has repaid her entire loan well. She also managed to pay tuition for four of her children.

She has now applied for a loan of 800,000 UGX to buy more stock of clothes; this being a festive season, she believes she will make more sales since many people will be buying new clothes.

Her major challenge is high transport costs from the city to where she sells them and taxes which eat into her profits, coupled with the fact that she has to meet her family demands single handedly.

Despite these challenges Saidat is very hard-working and committed, striving to provide a better life and education for her children.

loans.use: To buy second-hand clothes to sell.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en:
Robert is a married man, age 42, with 6 children.  Four attend school in different areas. He lives in a rural setting with his family. He deals in farming and cattle keeping, which he considers as his side income; he started his business in 1990.

He works six days a week and started a business to get enough food and capital for the family. 

He has acquired this loan for cattle fattening and buying of fertilizer for the banana plantation.  He said his clients are traders from cities and people in his village.

His hopes are to be the leading supplier of bananas and cattle products, and to educate his children. 

He faces challenges of too much drought and lack of enough capital, which affects the productivity rate which in turn affects his income growth.

He is a hard working man.In the photo is the client (on the right )and the Ugafode credit credit Officer.

loans.use: To buy cattle and organic fertilizer

loans.name: Estrellas De Llanquichapi Group

texts.es:
La A.C. “ESTRELLITAS DE LLANQUICHAPI”  iniciará el primer ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Copacabana, está compuesta por ocho integrantes y está dirigida por una mesa directiva donde la señora Margarita es la Presidenta. Los negocios que las integrantes de la asociación comunal llevan adelante son variados entre ellos existen: venta de pan de laja, venta de pescado, venta de cerveza, venta de carne, venta de verduras.

El crédito que sacaran beneficiara a pequeñas microempresarias donde la señora Margarita es integrante, ella indica que es la primera vez que integra Pro Mujer, ingresando por invitación de una promotora de la institución que fue a visitarle a su casa. En la actualidad ella tiene un negocio de venta de pescado; cuenta que este negocio lo implemento por recomendación de su padre quien le enseño este negocio desde niña, cuando tuvo su primer hijo decide implementar su negocio independientemente.
 
El crédito que ahora sacará es para el aumento de capital (compra de red de pesca) que adquirirá de las vendedoras mayoristas de la Ciudad de La Paz y posteriormente lo implementará en su espacio de pesca. Esta forma de trabajo le permite generar recursos para mantener en lo posible a su hogar pues ella es soltera y tiene cinco hijos.  

Cuando se le consulta qué le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella responde que le gusta las capacitaciones que ofrece la institución.
texts.en:
The Estrellitas de Llanquichapi communal bank will begin its first cycle with Pro Mujer as part of the Copacabana regional hub.  It is made up of eight members and is lead by a Board of Directors, of which Señora Margarita is president.  The businesses that the communal bank members carry out are varied.  Among them are: flatbread sales, beer sales, meat sales, and vegetables sales.

The loan that they are taking out will benefit these small-time microentrepreneurs, of which Señora Margarita is one.  She says that this is her first time with Pro Mujer.  She joined due to an invitation from a promoter of the organization who went to visit her in her home.  She currently has a business selling fish.  She says that she began this business on the advice of her father, who taught her the trade from the time she was a girl.  When she had her first child she decided to start her own business.

The loan that she is taking out now is to increase her capital for the purchase of a fishing net which she will get from the wholesale suppliers in the city of La Paz.  Later she will use it in her fishing business.  This type of work lets her generate income to support her home as well as possible, because she is single and has five children.

When she is asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she answers that she likes the training sessions the organization offers.

loans.use: to buy a fish net.

loans.name: Hong's Group

texts.en:
Hong was born in 1954. Her husband passed away. She has 3 children, all of whom have been married. Hong has been a farmer for 30 years. Her monthly income is only about VND 2,000,000.  Her dream is having enough money to build a new house.  Thus, to raise more income for her family, besides growing crops, Hong raises chickens and pigs to sell eggs and meat. However, she is facing the problem of capital shortage to invest in her farming business. Consequently, she would like to participate in this credit program to solve her financial difficulty. Hong has been a member of SEDA since 2006. This time, she would like to borrow VND 10,682,000 to buy piglets, chicks and animal fodder. Her profits from her business will be used to fulfill her dream, which is owning a new house. 
Other members of Hong's  group are:
•	Xuyen is a 49 years old businesswoman. She has 2 children. She would love to borrow VND 7,630,000 to buy more fruits for her fruit shops.
•	Sau is 54 years old. She is a distiller. She wants to borrow VND 11,118,000 to invest in her distillation workshop.
•	Mai is a 47 years old businesswoman. She would like to borrow VND 10,246,000 to restocking her grocery shop.
•	Hanh is 39 years old. She has 2 children. She wants to borrow 10, 246,000 to finance her family business, which is a clothes shop.
•	Thanh is 28 years old. She has 2 children. She wants to borrow 10,682,000 to invest in her fish shop in a local market.
•	Ngoc is 36 years old. She has 2 children. Similar to Hong, Ngoc, she wants to borrow VND 7,630,000 for raising poultry. 
•       Ton is 63 years old. She has 2 children. She would love to borrow VND 11,118,000 VND to invest in her breakfast restaurant

loans.use: to buy piglets, chicks, and animal fodder

loans.name: Ailsa Da Conceiçao

texts.en:
She is 26 years old. She is single and she has two children. She lives in a rented house. She started in this activity since when she was younger with her mother. When she turned 20 years she started to do her own business. Since she has gained some skill in this area, she has a great desire to grow in this business but she was needing part of the money to start her own job. 
We think that she has gained some experience and she also has a great desire and knows how to use the loan that's we consider these things as the main factors to help her, and so we had financed her for the first loan and she reimbursed on time as the agreement previously made. Now it'll be her second loan!

loans.use: To buy produce to sell in other  islands.

loans.name: Fatmata B.

texts.en:
This is 48-year-old Fatmata B. She is divorced and has two children, ages 28 and 26 years, all are school going children. She has one additional dependent who live with her to be fostered. In 2011, Fatmata B. established her provisions business, selling sweet milk, soft drinks, ovaltine, sugar, tea leaf, biscuit, and mayonnaise. 

She began her business after her husband divorced her. He gave her some amount of money for her and the children's up keeping. She used the money to start a business. Working seven days a week and 11 hours a day, she earns about SLL 760,000 every month from this business. 

She would like a loan in the amount of SLL 3,000,000. Fatmata B. requires a loan in order to buy ovaltine, mosquito coil, sugar and soft drinks. In the future, Fatmata B. plans to acquire a piece of land, perform Hajj, and expand the business. Her main challenge is that the sales are sometimes slow.    She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy Ovaltine, mosquito coil, sugar, and soft drinks.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a food vender.  She prepares a variety of food for sale.  Some of the food is banku and vegetable soup.  Banku is a traditional Ghanaian dish made using fermented corn/cassava dough that is mixed proportionally and cooked in hot water until it is the consistency of a smooth whitish paste.  

With years of expereince in this business, she is currently looking to expand her enterprise further. Unfortunately, she is limited due to a lack of funding. As a result, this loan will be used to help her purchase more maize and cassava, fish and vegetables, thus enabling her to prepare and sell more of her tasty ‘Banku’ and soup. 

She aims at using the profits from her business to help support her husband (who is a terrazzo floor designer) with the upkeep of their house whilst ensuring that their four children are able to experience a better life.

loans.use: purchase more maize and cassava, fish and vegetables, thus enabling her to prepare and sell more of her tasty ‘Banku’ and soup.

loans.name: Banco Mujer Mujeres Del Futuro Group

texts.es:
Banco Mujer Mujeres del futuro  está integrado por cinco mujeres que ya han recibido crédito anterior para el desarrollo de sus proyectos agropecuarios y de comercio.
Yesenia es la presidenta del grupo, vive en unión libre son el padre de sus 2 hijos menores de edad.  Se dedica al desarrollo y engorde de cerdos, gracias a está actividad contribuye a cubrir los gastos familiares ya que su compañero trabaja en lo propio y recibe un salario muy bajo.  Este es su tercer crédito y lo va a invertir en la compra de cerdos, alimentos, vitaminas y otros. Esto le va a permitir aumentar su producción, así como los ingresos al hogar mejorando la calidad de vida de ella y su familia.
texts.en:
Five women are members of this Fundacion Mujer "Mujeres del Futuro" group. They have previously received credit for the development of agricultural and commerce projects.

Yesenia is the president of the group. She lives in a civil union with the father of her two children who are young in age. She works on raising and fattening pigs. She is thankful for this activity because it allows her to cover the costs of her family since her husband does the same thing and receives a low salary. This is her third loan, and she will invest in buying pigs, food, vitamins, and other things. This will allow her to increase her production and her income in order to improve the quality of life for her and her family.

loans.use: to buy piglets for fattening, food, raw materials for food production, and catalog supplies

loans.name: Juana

texts.es: Juana agradece a los inversionistas por el préstamo y se siente contenta por el apoyo brindado, ella quiere continuar participando en este proyecto porque le ayuda a incrementar el capital del negocio y también se siente motivada para continuar trabajando en  su negocio, ella continua con el negocio de la elaboración de pan entonces en esta oportunidad requiere el préstamo para comprar insumos como por ejemplo harina, azúcar,  manteca y mantequilla.
texts.en:
Juana thanks the investors for the loan and is happy for the support given. She wishes to continue participating in this project because it helps her increase her working capital. She also feels motivated to continue working in her business.

She continues with the business of making bread and in this opportunity needs the loan to buy ingredients such as flour, sugar, lard and butter.

loans.use: to buy ingredients such as flour, sugar, lard and butter.

loans.name: Kuña Guapa Group

texts.es:
Kuña Guapa está en su ciclo 7 del programa de comité de mujeres, donde todas y cada una está luchando por salir adelante y dar a sus familias lo que ellas no pudieron tener. Ellas también están dentro del programa de eliminación de pobreza, luchando por poder mejorar sus vidas y la de sus seres queridos.
Maria se dedica a la venta de comidas, ella misma las prepara y las sale a vender. Con mucho sacrificio está saliendo adelante y ayudando a su familia. Es una persona muy entusiasta que siempre está contenta en cada capacitación que recibe.
Ella pide de este crédito para poder invertirlo en la compra de verduras, carne, condimentos, y demás, que le permitirá seguir haciendo sus comidas para la venta, y mejorando sus ingresos.
texts.en:
Kuña Guapa is in its seventh loan cycle in the women's committee program.  Each and every one of them is striving to get ahead and give their families what they weren't able to have.  They are also in the poverty elimination program, striving to be able to improve life for themselves and their loved ones.

María earns a living selling food that she herself prepares and goes out to sell.  With a lot of hard work she's getting ahead and helping her family.  She's a very enthusiastic person who's always happy in the training sessions.

María's requesting this loan to be able to buy vegetables, meat, condiments, and other ingredients so she can keep on making her meals to sell and improving her income.

loans.use: to buy vegetables, meat, condiments, and other ingredients

loans.name: Isaac

texts.en:
Isaac lives in Maphombe, a small town in Kwale County. Kakamega is located in Western Kenya and is famous for the Kakamega Forest, the only tropical rain forest in Kenya. It is a very good location for beekeeping due to the old growth trees in the forest and the concentration of farms in the area, which provide bees with a variety of forage.

Isaac is married and has five children. Both he and his wife are farmers. They have been farming for 23 years and they are currently growing oranges on their farm. Isaac is excited about beekeeping because it will provide him with honey.

This is Isaac’s first loan with Honey Care. He intends to use the proceeds from his beehives to build a house for his family. Isaac’s hope for the future is to build a house for his family.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Ann Maa Basumata Shg Group

texts.en:
A 54-year-old mother of four children, Kuntala (in the picture the lady standing with raised hand) is a widow who currently only has one schoolchild under her dependency. As a single mother, she struggles in earning her daily cost of living through selling fish and a small grocery shop. For her eight year involvement in the current business, she is able to earn up to 7,000 Indian Rupees (INR) per month.

She is a first-time borrower with People's Forum, Kiva's partner, and feels very confident that she can upgrade her living in a gradual manner.

Now, to better support her business, she formed a group of ten members having the name Ann Maa Basumata SHG to request a loan. All the group members are female and all are engaged in different business activities like fish selling, vegetable selling, paddy cultivation etc. The total of her group loan loan is 250,000 INR. Kuntala will use her loan portion to buy grocery items to support her business. Moreover, she also wants to fix her house so it is in proper condition.

She hopes her business will improve progressively, and also hopes to have her house in good condition.

loans.use: To purchase grocery items in bulk like sugar, rice, raw dal, spices, biscuits, tea, flour etc. to support her business.

loans.name: Saybatou

texts.fr: Saybatou est cultivateur âgé de 72 ans il est marié et père de 15 enfants, il a commencé à exercer cette activité depuis qu'il est tout petit.Avec ce crédit,il va acheter du semence de tomate, d'onions, d'herbicide et d'engrais.
texts.en: Saybatou is a 72-year-old farmer, who is married and father to 15 children. He started this business when he was very young. With this loan, he will buy onion and tomato seeds, herbicide and fertilizer.

loans.use: Achat de semence de tomate, d'onions, d'herbicides et d'engrais.

loans.name: Khaly

texts.fr: Khaly est cultivateur âgé de 57 ans établi dans le département de Dagana, il est marié et père de 7 enfants. Il a commencé cette activité de maraîchage depuis qu'il est petit accompagné de ses parents. Avec ce crédit, il va acheter du semence de patate douce, d'herbicide et de fertilisants.
texts.en: Khaly is a 57-year-old farmer, who is married and a father to seven children. He lives in the department of Dagana. He has been working in farming with his parents since he was very young. He will buy sweet potato seedlings, herbicide and fertilizer.

loans.use: to buy sweet potato seedlings, herbicide and fertilizer

loans.name: Abdourahmane

texts.fr: Abdourahmane est cultivateur âgé de 47 ans il est marié et père de 6 enfants, il est établi dans le département de dagana, il a commencé cette activité de maraîchage depuis qu'il est tout petit. Avec ce crédit, il va acheter du semence de tomate, d'onions, d'herbicide et de l'engrais.
texts.en: Abdourahmane is a 47-year-old farmer, who is married and a father to six children. He lives in Dagana. He has been working in farming since he was very young with his parents. With this loan, he will buy onion and tomato seeds, herbicide and fertilizer.

loans.use: to buy onion and tomato seeds, herbicide and fertilizer

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba sells secondhand clothing in Domenase near Elmina.  She has had some form of formal education as she is a middle school graduate.  She is married and has two children.  Her husband is a mason.  

Aba has been working as a secondhand clothing seller for close to twenty years.  Her income is used to help her husband pay the utility bills and their children’s school fees.  She plans on using her loan to purchase an increased quantity of used clothing, thus allowing her to meet the rising demands of her customers.. 

She hopes to use the profits from her enterprise to fulfill her dream of buying a used clothing stand, hence helping her sell from a fixed location in the future.

loans.use: to purchase an increased quantity of used clothing, thus allowing her to meet the rising demands of her customers.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is married with three children.  She has received some schooling till the end of middle school.  

Currently, Jane sells kenkey, plantains, cassava, and oil in her village of Domenase near Elmina.  She has been involved in this industry for about twenty years now.  Her husband is a farmer and Jane’s income goes towards helping her husband pay for the family's general expenses.  

Jane will use the loan to increase her inventory of goods.  With the new profits from her expanded enterprise, Jane plans to develop her business further by venturing into newer markets.

loans.use: to increase her inventory of goods (kenkey, plantains, cassava, and oil )

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua is married with three children.  She received schooling through the end of junior high school.  

Currently, Ekua runs a drugstore in Domenase near Elmina.  She has been involved in this industry for about four years now.  Her husband is a taxi driver. Ekua’s income goes towards helping her husband pay for the family's general expenses. 

Ekua will use the loan to increase her drugstore’s inventory. With the new profits from her expanded enterprise, Ekua plans to develop her business further by venturing into newer markets.

loans.use: to increase her drugstore’s inventory.

loans.name: Maame

texts.en:
Although she has received no prior formal education, Maame is an entrepreneur.  She specializes in selling provisions in her village of Domenase near Elmina.  She has been involved in this enterprise for two years.  

Maame is married and has four children.  Her husband works as a farmer.  The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and to pay their children’s school fees. 

Maame wants to use her loan to increase her current inventory levels, hence allowing her to sell greater quantities of provisions.  In the long term, Maame plans to reinvest future profits into her business, thus helping her expand and meet increasing customer demands.

loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels, hence allowing her to sell greater quantities of provisions.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Although she has received no prior formal education, Esi is an entrepreneur.  She specializes in selling provisions in a village near Elmina.  She has been involved in this enterprise for thirteen years.  

Esi is married and has two children.  Her husband works as a trader.  The proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and pay their children’s school fees.  

Esi wants to use her loan to increase her current inventory levels, allowing her to sell greater quantities of provisions.  In the long term, Esi plans to reinvest future profits into her business, thus helping her expand and meet the needs of rising customer demands.

loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels, allowing her to sell greater quantities of provisions.

loans.name: Atta

texts.en:
Atta is a small scale grocer in Domenase near Elmina.  She has had some form of formal education as she is a junior high school graduate.  She is married and has one child. Her husband is a businessman. 

Atta has been working as a grocer for close to two years.  Her income is used to help her husband pay the utility bills and their children’s school fees.
 
She plans on using her loan to purchase a greater quantity of groceries, thus allowing her to meet rising customer demands. She hopes to use the profits from her enterprise to fulfill her dream of owning stores in multiple locations.

loans.use: to purchase more groceries for resale.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba is married with five children. She has received some schooling till the end of middle school. Currently, Aba is a food vendor, selling dishes like rice with stew in Domenase near Elmina. She has been involved in this industry for about ten years now. Her husband is a mason. Aba’s income goes towards helping her husband pay for the family's general expenses. 

Aba will use the loan to purchase more ingredients to make her tasty food. With the new profits from her expanded enterprise, Aba plans to develop her business further by venturing into newer markets.

loans.use: to purchase more ingredients to make her tasty food.

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama is a small scale plantain seller in her village of Domenase near Elmina. She has had some form of formal education as she is a junior high school graduate. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a poultry farmer. Ama has been selling plantains for close to eight years. Her income is used to help her husband pay the utility bills and their children’s school fees. She plans on using her loan to purchase an increased quantity of plantains, thus allowing her to meet rising customers’ demands. She hopes to use the profits from her enterprise to fulfill her dream of buying a plantain stand, hence helping her sell from a fixed location in the future.

loans.use: to purchase an increased quantity of plantains, thus allowing her to meet rising customer demand.

loans.name: Aya Duku

texts.en:
Aya operates a provisions store business in her village of Domenase near Elmina. Aya is a widow with three children. As the sole breadwinner in the family, Aya uses her income to provide for the entire family. Aya will use the loan to purchase increased amounts of provisions, thus helping her to improve her overall sales. 

As a junior high school graduate, Aya understands the importance of education in improving social conditions, thus she plans to use the profits from her expanded enterprise to ensure that all her children remain in school.

loans.use: to purchase increased amounts of provisions for her store.

loans.name: Nana Ama

texts.en: Nana is involved in selling watermelon in her village of Domenase near Elmina. Her earnings are generally used to help her husband (who is a taxi driver) support their three children. She has been involved in selling watermelon for five years now. She plans on using her loan to purchase additional amounts of melon, thus helping her sell more due to increased inventory capacity. She aspires to use her profits to both better market her watermelon enterprise and to increase her existing working capital. She hopes that this strategy will allow her to expand her present customer base.

loans.use: to purchase additional amounts of melons.

loans.name: Ekua Akosua

texts.en: Even though Ekua grew up in poverty without an education, this has not stopped her from fulfilling her dream of achieving a better life for her and her family. Currently, Ekua is a hairdresser in her village of Domenase near Elmina. Her business enterprise has grown substantially since she began eleven years ago.Ekua is married and has five children.Her husband is a herbalist. he proceeds from her business normally go towards helping her husband cover the family’s general expenses and pay their children’s school fees.Ekua wants to use her loan to increase her current inventory levels of hair extensions and other hair products, hence allowing her to better meet the needs of her customers. In the long term, Ekua plans to reinvest future profits into her business, thus helping her expand and meet the needs of rising customer demands.

loans.use: to increase her current inventory levels of extensions and other hair products, allowing her to better meet the needs of her customers.

loans.name: Maame

texts.en: Maame is single and has two children. After successfully graduating from junior high school, Maame is now an established businesswoman. She sells watermelon in Domenase near Elmina. She has been actively involved in this business for about three years. As the sole breadwinner, Maame uses her income to provide for the entire family. Maame will use the loan to purchase increased amounts of watermelon, thus aiding her to improve her overall sales. With the new profits from her expanded business, Maame plans to diversify the type of products that she sells, hence adapting to changing customers' preferences.

loans.use: to purchase more watermelon and increase her sales.

loans.name: Philip

texts.en:
Philip lives in Kakamega. Kakamega county is located in Western Kenya and is famous for having the only tropical rain forest in the country. Most farmers in Kakamega grow maize, but sugarcane, papaya, bananas and tea are also popular crops. The variety of crops grown in the region, as well as the abundance of vegetation in the old growth forest, make Kakamega particularly attractive for beekeeping. 

Philip is married and has six children. His wife is a nurse while he undertakes farming. He has been farming for three years and he is currently growing vegetables in greenhouses. Philip is excited about beekeeping because it will earn him some income.

This is Philip’s first loan with Honey Care. He intends to use the proceeds from his beehives to pay school fees for his children and to maintain his home. Philip’s future hope is to be able to package his honey and sell it, and to educate the community on beekeeping.

loans.use: to buy beehives for honey production.

loans.name: Jeremiah

texts.en:
Philip lives in Kakamega. Kakamega is located in Western Kenya and is famous for the Kakamega Forest, the only tropical rain forest in Kenya. It is a very good location for beekeeping due to the old growth trees in the forest and the concentration of farms in the area, which provide bees with a variety of foliage.

Philip is married and has six children. His wife is a nurse, while he works in the farming industry. He has been farming for three years and he is currently growing vegetables in greenhouses. Philip is excited about beekeeping because it would help him earn some extra income.

This would be Philip’s first loan through Honey Care. He would like to use the proceeds to purchase beehives. He intends to use any income he generates from his beekeeping activities to pay for his children's school fees and to maintain his home. Philip’s hope for the future is to be able to package his honey for re-sale and to educate the community on beekeeping.

loans.use: to produce honey by purchasing beehives

loans.name: Ihusi Group

texts.fr: La cliente Zahiga est une commerçante depuis 3 ans et membré d’un groupe d’affaires « Ihusi », âgée de 31 ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants qui tous, étudient. Elle est vendeuse  des  poissons  frais. Elle étale sa marchandise tout au long de la route dans un quartier animé. Elle sollicite un prêt auprès de Hekima pour accroitre ses activités. Elle va acheter 250 poissons frais. Son conjoint,lui aussi, est commerçant. Elle avait commencé ses business avec de fonds reçu de son mari. Dans l’avenir, elle souhaite accroitre son capital,  scolariser, vêtir et nourrir ses enfants. Elle remercie Hekima pour le soutien, qu’elle apporte aux femmes entrepreneurs non bancable. Il sied de signaler certaines clientes portent leur bébés.
texts.en:
Zahiga has been a merchant for three years and is a member of the business group "Ihusi." She is 31 years old, married, and a mother of four children, who all go to school.

Zahiga sells fresh fish. She displays her fish along a road in a busy part of town. She is seeking a loan with Hekima in order to expand her business. She is going to buy 250 fresh fish.

Her husband also is a merchant. She had started her business with funds she received from her husband.

In the future, she wishes to increase her capital, and educate, clothe, and feed her children. 

Zahiga thanks Hekima for their support to female entrepreneuers who do not qualify for banking services. 

To note, there are some clients who are carrying their children and some other curious children who have climbed on the wall in the photo.

loans.use: to buy 250 fresh fish

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: 3.03.805.09.thiệu Lý Group

texts.en:
Luận is applying for a loan to purchase calves to raise and sell in the future.  She works in agriculture, raising poultry and cattle.  Luận is 55 years old and she is married with 2 children.  She is the group leader of the 3.03.805.09.Thiệu Lý solidarity group, which consists of 4 members.  She lives and works in Thieu Hoa district, a rural area in Thanh Hoa province.

In 2011, Luận joined the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business.  She has successfully repaid 3 loans from the Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Luận has been involved in this business for more than 10 years.  The main hardship that Luận faces in her business is the lack of capital.  With her business profit, Luận hopes for her business to do well and for her children to find a good job.

loans.use: to purchase calves to raise and sell in the future

loans.name: Jaqueline Karina

texts.es:
Jaqueline vive en la ciudad de chincha, ciudad que se caracteriza porque es la cuna de grandes glorias del deporte peruano, así como también porque sus pobladores son muy conocidos por la buena sazón que tienen para la preparación de platillos. Con mucho esfuerzo Jaqueline inicio su negocio de preparación y venta de dulces como tortas, alfajores, panes, gelatinas, entre otros; ella se dedica a su negocio alrededor de 8 horas,  ella tiene una buena sazón para los dulces y por ello ella cree que le va bien en su negocio, además de atender con mucha amabilidad a sus clientes ya que la mayoría son niños y siempre les tiene paciencia.

Jaqueline está muy agradecida con los prestatarios kiva ya que es la segunda vez que le brindan su apoyo y en esta oportunidad podrá  gracias a su ayuda ella podrá realizar un mantenimiento a su horno, y comprar utensilios de repostería, lo que le permitirá poder tener mejores utensilios para realizar mejor su trabajo, así ella seguirá luchando para poder cumplir su gran sueño:” Tener su empresa de repostería y panadería y preparar los mejores dulces de su ciudad y sobre todo darle una profesión a sus hijos”.
texts.en:
Jaqueline lives in the city of Chincha, which is known for being the birthplace of great Peruvian sports heroes as well as for the flavorful way of cooking for which its residents are famous.   

Through a great effort, Jaqueline started her business, making and selling pastries such as cakes, cookie sandwiches, breads, jellies, and such. She works at her business for about 8 hours, and she has a gift for baking pastries. For this reason she believes that she will do well in her business, and also because she is very friendly to her customers, as most of them are children with whom she is always patient.

Jaqueline is very grateful to the Kiva lenders, as this is the second time that they have given her their support.  With this opportunity, thanks to their help, she will be able to carry out  maintenance on her oven and purchase pastry making utensils so that she will have better tools for doing her work.

This way she will continue fighting to fulfill her great dream: “To have her pastry and baking company, to make the best pastries in the city, and above all, to give her children a profession.”

loans.use: to repair her oven and purchase pastry making utensils

loans.name: Lungujja Kwekulakulanya Group

texts.en:
Florence, 35,  is a married resident of Lungujja with four children. She has a very big responsibility of taking care of her children by providing them with good education, shelter, clothing and medical care, since her husband is jobless.

She operates a small restaurant along the road and this is where she has earned a living that has sustained her family. She has been in this business for two years and has a dream of expanding it into a bigger restaurant.
